author: {'steamid': '76561198092467769', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 471, 'last_played': 1710448315}
review:
This was a fun, short little space adventure game with witty humor and good music. The combat is nothing too special, if you are looking for something that's much heavier on the combat/ space sandbox side of things, check out Starsector. But this is a fun little game to play over a weekend and it is usually on sale for the cheap. 

TLDR: 8/10 good game would buy again

author: {'steamid': '76561199069647492', 'num_games_owned': 208, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 959, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 959, 'last_played': 1609846679}
review:
Un'avventura open-world che preme sull'acceleratore della nostalgia e propone un mix eterogeneo di elementi che danno vita ad un insieme dannatamente accattivante. Questa odissea spaziale segue le gesta di John Falcon, pilota mercenario e cacciatore di taglie, con il look alla Indiana Jones. Ricorda qualcuno? Il citazionismo non si limita al personaggio principale ma si estende ad una trama declinata perlopiù in maniera umoristica. Non mancano comunque momenti più dark ed un paio di buoni colpi di scena. 
Il gameplay di 3030 Deathwar Redux è suddiviso principalmente in tre sezioni. Passeremo la maggior parte del tempo a pilotare l'astronave di Falcon con una visuale dall'alto. Nello spazio la lista di missioni che non seguono la trama principale e che ci permettono di guadagnare preziosi crediti ha una discreta varietà, sebbene non eccelsa. Si comincia con semplici lavori da tassista o corriere spaziale, ma una volta che riusciremo ad acquistare una nave dotata di armi verranno sbloccate missioni di scorta o che prevedono di dare la caccia ad una flottiglia di pirati. Ed è qui che la colonna sonora riveste la parte del leone. Il pop elettronico e un po' ruffiano del gruppo The Kyoto Connection dà ottime vibrazioni e rende la navigazione nello spazio ancora più godibile. Quando ci troveremo all'interno di una stazione spaziale prenderemo il controllo del prode Falcon in una visuale a scorrimento laterale. Qui l'estetica da avventura grafica vecchio stile è al servizio della narrazione e della customizzazione della nostra nave. Saltuariamente nelle fasi più avanzate ci sarà anche qualche sparatoria. L'ultimo segmento riguarda l'esplorazione dei derelitti delle astronavi che all'inizio aggiunge ulteriore varietà ma finisce per stancare abbastanza in fretta. Questo non vale per il gioco nel suo insieme ed ho perso il conto di quante volte ho detto la fatidica frase "ancora un'altra missione e poi chiudo".

author: {'steamid': '76561197968598435', 'num_games_owned': 2383, 'num_reviews': 129, 'playtime_forever': 501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 501, 'last_played': 1702840538}
review:
A quick and easy space adventure. Trade, bounty hunt, mine, scavenge, and use the money to upgrade your ship... without much grind. Especially if you do a few easy money things the game throws at you.

Good campy / comedy action movie storyline. There's also some licensed music from Kyoto Connection which bills itself as "80s style pop music" and yeah, it's that.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996781342', 'num_games_owned': 828, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 550, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 285, 'last_played': 1705260525}
review:
This game takes me back to the 90s, being 10 years old playing DOS games on my Dad's computer.  The humor, the game play, all of it.  

Highly recommend if you are into old Sierra/Lucas Arts adventure games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198253040073', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 2044, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2044, 'last_played': 1684258125}
review:
Historic Review:  Games I played months if not years ago – I decided to start reviewing right at the end of 2023!  Memory of a trepanned, ADHD toddler with impulse control issues notwithstanding.  

Teaboy's Basic(ish) Reviews....I read a lot of reviews when looking at games on Steam, and it quickly gets tiring – those who write involved, down to the micron scale reviews, although helpful, end up like looking at War & Peace when you’ve only got time for a quick 5 minute dump!  This is middle of the road and to the point – not easy for me as I tend towards sesquipedalian loquaciousness!  Vociferously Verbose?  Alright, verbal diarrhoea.  (Although I hate panning a developer’s work and all the time, effort and love they put into designing these – it is their life after all – this is my honest, personal opinion of my level of enjoyment.  Sorry devs!).  

A note on time played:  My Steam clock does not seem to work properly, indeed, it even minuses time on occasion!  Plus, I have a tendency to wander off and leave games running at times, so time played may not be entirely accurate!  


Teaboy’s Tonsil Titillators or Toenail Titbits!  (Rating)  

Tonsil Tickler (Totally Tops):  The frenchy of which you always dreamt!  To quote a master, “She’s got a tongue like an electric eel and she likes the taste of a Man’s tonsils!”.  An absolute masterpiece and joy to play.  

The Tits (Terrific):  Everyone loves playing with these!  Not THE best bit, but such fun on their own you can be lost for hours....mmmm.  What most games you really like score – perfection is so rare after all.   

Torso Teaser (Taker of your Time):  It’s a flat stomach....sure it’s nice to look at, run your fingers over, slobber on a bit, sometimes that bellybutton gets your motor running....but it's just basically the corridor between the two ‘gaming rooms’.  The definitive ‘Meh’ - the middle ‘sideways thumb’ option for which everyone on Steam cries.  

Todger/Tadger & (scroTum) Taters (Tedious):  Is it an ‘a’ or is it an ‘o’?  Who cares!  The meat can be fun to play with for about 5 minutes of your entire day, the rest it just hangs there and generally gets in the way of doing something else.  The main problem of course, is the two veg sticking to your inside thigh.  This is what this game feels like – the occasional/rare bouts of fun, the rest bobbing like a 19th century British Policeman (now you know why!).  

Toenail Tornado (Total Toss):  A playthrough so appalling it’s like being trapped in a Turkish sauna with the ugliest, hairiest, fattest, sweatiest beast of a neolithic hominid who’s trimming his toenails using pliers and the splinters are reminiscent of a scene from the Normandy Landings.  My god how did this get released!?  


Teaboy Touts (Score):  TONSIL TICKLER!!


The Review:  

They took 10 years to make this game....TEN YEARS!  And it shows because the game is flawless!  

Its simplicity is what makes it work - it's just fun!  Pixel graphics!?  I mean, wtf!?  And yet....magic.  You just keep wanting to get out there and splash pirate scum all over the spacelanes!  Why?  To get the cash to install the stash to make the splash!  Bigger better guns, faster more explodery mis-kiles, and that marvellous looking superduperuber-ship!  

When you start the game you're earning hundreds - when you find a system that sells the top ships they're in the Millions!  You think you're never going to get there, but you earn some dough, you buy a bigger gun, you learn to kill bigger baddies, you haul more parcels, you buy another ship with passenger space, you turn into a taxi/delivery service.  Money comes in, you buy another ship that can actually turn^^  You shoot stuff, you try your first missile, you start to buy all the bits n bobs available to upgrade your ship.  You think, "Wow, this reward is 10k for this pirate....can I?"  You give it a go, you waste that mother....the world opens up to you.  One moment you're a newt, next you're a naughty-bottomed chocolate coconut bar capturer!  

It's just a joy to play, pure and simple.  The most common thing said about this game is the desire for it to be longer.  No greater compliment can be given to a game other than people want to Keep playing it.  But then the these things are considered marvels of their ilk exactly because they end before they unravel - how many things have we had/eaten/watched etc that we thought were absolutely brilliant....until they made another one, and then another.  The gem became cloudy, the heart of it slowly poisoned, the colour drained and the soul died.  Keep 'em wanting more.  

Oh, and the scanner thing - one mission!  You can scan EVERYONE!  The entire galaxy worth of characters, and it is pointless!  Just that one person for that one mission.  Shame they never expanded upon its use.  And the ship scanner too - let's face it, you're just gonna blow ship up regardless of its content^^  

Don't bother trying to map the clouds, it doesn't affect you enough to matter.  And for those on larger aspect ratios, the bottom of the screen has a tiny line of script that is vital in a later mission searching for a satellite - there's a verbal diarrhoea post in discussions from me exactly about it^^  

Just play it, it has a magic about it that makes it....magic.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963896969', 'num_games_owned': 899, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1012, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1012, 'last_played': 1688988952}
review:
Honestly worth it for the soundtrack alone, discovering The Kyoto Connection was a delight.

That being said, the game is solid. Lots of mechanical crunch (you'll be upgrading your ship for a /while/), different approaches and styles to what ship you want to fly, a high skill ceiling for flying, and a beautiful world to explore. Flying your ship feels lovely, too, especially given the plethora of ships to get and upgrades to buy, there's almost always something new to try out.

My two gripes are:

It seems like you hit a bit of a wall with income potential. You'll run into ships that cost millions and still be getting 10-50k jobs. Entirely possible this is a skill issue, I haven't played for too long and haven't looked up any guides for it.

The music is wonderful, and there's a field in the escape/settings menu under "sound" that tries to show the artist and title currently playing, and even throws in a "next song" button for good measure. All of this is wonderful, I wish more games did this. However, the artist/track-name field is a bit messy, I've seen it show artist - album, or album - track name. Given that there isn't a separate game soundtrack to buy as DLC, this made looking up the songs I fell in love with a challenge, but certainly not impossible.

author: {'steamid': '76561198972525162', 'num_games_owned': 233, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2818, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2818, 'last_played': 1675759044}
review: 3030 Deathwar Redux: A Space Odyssey is an absolute gem that takes you on an unforgettable voyage through the vastness of space. As a fan of sci-fi and exploration games, I was immediately drawn to this title, and I'm thrilled to say that it exceeded all my expectations.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044114273', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 703, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 703, 'last_played': 1686670699}
review: Old-school 2D adventure, exploration, and combat...IN SPACE! 3030 DR is so many cool things crammed into a tiny package. (Side-scrolling adventure, action-RPG, top-down space shooter/sim, etc.) If you can live with the limited resolution options of the game engine (max rec.: 720p,) then grab your sense of humor and dive in. This game will surprise you. Good stuff.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003119873', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 134, 'last_played': 1529807597}
review:
I recommend this game if you like to jam to 80's sounding music and like side scrollers. The music is amazing the dialog is funny and  entertaining. As far as difficulty goes I think a 4 year old can handle it.

There is a lot of back and forth and a little difficult trying to figure out where the heck to go at times.
quick pace combat with plenty of crap on the screen to blind you at every point.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971971321', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 2701, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2511, 'last_played': 1685300484}

author: {'steamid': '76561197971330292', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 1114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1114, 'last_played': 1684877036}
review:
To summarize, this is a great little game. Worth every penny, especially when it is on sale. The great soundtrack and the novel 2D point and click style are really good. I hope there will be a sequel, or another deeper game based on the same ideas.

I took it as a more relaxing game rather than a hardcore simulation and I had a lot of fun.

Just don’t take too much time to grind stuff. Enjoy the story! Or else you will be bored by the possible repetitiveness of the side quests. I played for about 18 hours without grinding, just having fun, and I was able to finish the story without problems.

What I liked:
* The soundtrack is incredibly great for such “little” game.
* The 2D graphics are charming.
* I love the 2D point and click interface when in station: This is much better than a menu or a crappy 3D rendering like in X4. It is quick and immersive. Plus, there are really pseudo point and click parts in the story!
* Freedom is here. Despite simple missions, you can decide how to grow your “character” and how go thought the story.

What could be better:
* The gameplay is good but repetitive. Maybe something like 10 different tasks. But that’s fine if you don’t grind: Just follow the story line, while doing side missions on the way…
* There is no real customization concerning your ship. There is a good variety of ships available of all kinds and tiers. However, equipment-wise, while you have a lot of modules to install, there is no real choice: just pick the most expensive one you can afford in each category. There is no “build” per say, like in Eve Online for example.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001236026', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 972, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 972, 'last_played': 1676829258}
review:
The story picks up quickly and the music is full of 80's energy. The arc of suspense dropped a little for me as I was just farming for the best upgrades and better ships. A few hours later it picked up again for the finale, but the game never felt as fantastic as the  first two hours.

Graphics work well together, the interface is weird but works and space fighting is engaging. FYI: When you accidentally shoot a space station or an NPC and everyone tries to kill you: Just give the next police ship a call and tell them you'll pay the fines and they'll stop.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032052135', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 1048, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1048, 'last_played': 1676668725}
review: I really enjoyed this game. The ship stuff is fun and surprisingly deep, the story and characters are cute and funny and there are tons of little easter egg references to great sci fi all over the place.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032414585', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2061, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2058, 'last_played': 1711239443}
review:
3030 Deathwar, what can you say about this game?  Killer music while cruising the stars, cargo trading, mining, and a bit of space combat to brighten your day.  If that's all it had, it would be an OK game, but it has a story that's actually pretty good in a cheesy sci-fi sort of way.  

So, if you like space sims, if you like flying around completing missions, and you want a fun plot to follow, this is for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097310869', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 635, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 635, 'last_played': 1526603247}

author: {'steamid': '76561198373241597', 'num_games_owned': 1629, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 6188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6188, 'last_played': 1675746550}
review:
Ugh I freaking hate this game.
I enjoyed playing it for the duration of the story, but the completion requirements are absurd.
The last achievement takes twice as long as the whole game.
So yeah it was fun and entertaining for a while, but I felt forced to play much much more than I wanted to, and I ended up hating the whole process.
The music is kinda good though, until the tenth time you hear the same song and realize you're listening to christian rock.
All in all I would recommend playing but not compelting

author: {'steamid': '76561197991388908', 'num_games_owned': 336, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 953, 'last_played': 1674781345}
review: It's easy to turn these kinds of games into a slog, where your missions around different star systems become rote and tedious, but somehow 3030 Deathwar avoids this.  I've been sticking to story missions in my last few hours, and still dip into doing side missions just because they're fun.  They're easy to get, easy to find, and solved quickly.  This makes for a really compelling game - the main missions are new things to do, but the side jobs are still fun, earn money for new toys, and encourage trying new things.  Really fun game, definitely worth full price if you like the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974782836', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1251, 'last_played': 1674609074}
review: poorly optimized. Cant seem to remember that I enable the controller each time I run the game. Cant save if I have an active mission. Gameplay is redundant and has little to no flavor. The only good thing is the art and some of the dialogue.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970250774', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 1476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1476, 'last_played': 1674214215}
review:
I will always be looking for games like this. They fill a niche in my childhood I will always want to fill.

This title scratches the edges of the itch, but unfortunately I think too many decisions were based on what is easier to develop ending up with a game that goes backwards from the retro games of old.

Firstly I enjoyed the writing – spoofy style humorous and engaging.
But then...

[b]Entering space stations[/b] seems fun, but ends up just tediously talking to people with filler text.
[list]
[*]not an improvement from classic dialogue popups (needs an important conversation indicator at minimum)
[/list]

[b] Scavenging derelicts [/b] also seems like a great idea, but again just ends up being tedious. Weapon aiming is janky, and there is no risk reward type of gameplay. You end up just mononotonously looting everything (cargo space allowing).
[list]
[*]not an improvement on a [loot] option popup.
[/list]

These could be easily overlooked as long as the core gameplay is fun...
...yeah you know where I'm going.

[b]Tailoring your ideal ship[/b] is a big part of this sort of game, but here it just comes down to buying everything you can afford. Buying a new ship affects movement stats and cargo space, but everything else is based on optional (unlimited) addons.
[olist]
[*]You can only have the one weapon. No optimising for multiple weapons/energy/heat limitations. Just choose one weapon (the best you can afford) and that's it. Well you can install a turret sure, but that halves the damage of your weapons so pretty much no change.
[*]There are no hard points or slots for addons. If you can afford it you can have all addons (including shield strength) on any ship.
[*]Addons are in a big list without any sorting. Makes it tedious to find and unequip your previous crud shield to install a better one for example.
[*]Some addons are single use - requiring you to find and purchase it in the list off all addons each time you use it.
[/olist]
Lastly [b]UI and in game interaction[/b] isn't great. You can't target specific space objects or tab through all enemies. The keybind always selects the closest enemy/station/friendly etc. oh yeah you can't change keybinds...


All up I did have fun for a bit, and have no issue supporting the devs (as I selfishly want more games like this). Unfortunately most design elements seem to fall short. I'm ok with that mostly, but it ends up being tedious and doesn't quite hit the mark.

If you do decide to give it a go at least you know what you're in for.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973353523', 'num_games_owned': 1093, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 867, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 351, 'last_played': 1691032324}

As many others have pointed out it really fills that void left by older games such as Escape Velocity and (more recently) Endless Sky.  With a touch of on foot (and floating!) exploration, it's a great package.

And the soundtrack is an absolute BANGER...as the kids say nowadays...

author: {'steamid': '76561198033064705', 'num_games_owned': 769, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 23, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1662175048}
review: The sound won't play. I have a modern Alienware PC. Sometimes I get sound but as soon as I change the resolution and have to restart the game their won't be any sound. No music or sound effects. Sometimes in the starting resolution it plays sound. But I can't bring myself to play this game in such a small aspect ratio. Wasted my money as I bought this on Humble Bundle and can't get a refund. Was really looking forward to this game but can't play it without sound. It was released back in 2017 so I doubt by 2022 or later this sound bug will ever be fixed. After some Googling their are other issues with the sound where it will just cut out after playing for a few hours, but I couldn't find anyone talking about having no sound at all in higher resolutions like 1440p. Very disappointed.
developer_response:
Hi pyroflamegames,

we're sorry to hear about the sound issue. You're right, I also checked the forums for anyone having this issue before and couldn't find any. And it's really weird that it only happens when you change the resolution of the game.

- Does the sound always work fine in the starting resolution?
- Is the starting resolution the wrong aspect ratio or just a lower resolution than your screen?
- Do you have any other sound software running that could be getting prioritized over the game?

author: {'steamid': '76561197967458277', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1837, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1834, 'last_played': 1657769754}
review:
This game was a wonderful surprise; scratched an itch I didn't know I had and I wish there was more! A sequel, a DLC, anything.

Progression is just right if you take a little time to explore and upgrade in between story line objectives. Combat is a thing but can be mostly avoided if you want a more laid-back time. Or in the options you can turn on a setting that has hit squads come at you with varying frequency and intensity which can be a great way to get that kill count up and score lots of rare loot - although I wouldn't do this until at [i]least[/i] mid-game as it can get pretty intense on the harder settings!

You'll run a lot of courier missions, and at least initially be doing some pretty low-volume trading. Salvage ops are entertaining for a while - make sure you explore completely and if you're lucky enough to encounter enemies shoot them until they drop gems for some extra cash. Salvage is also the best way to unlock the map, as about 1:6 crates will have pieces for you.

Go mining for a quick boost to the wallet (only mine the rarest ores to make it time well spent). I made a habit to swing through any asteroid field that was nearby to look for rare minerals real quick when returning to a station - just fill up an inventory with the rarest stuff for some extra cash at the expense of a minute or two.

While commodities have fluctuating values, [b]ship equipment stays the same and you can unequip/sell your gear at 100% purchase price[/b] to try other setups out with no loss. This is a really nice feature in the game as the weapons handle differently and just because one is more expensive doesn't necessarily mean it's better to your playstyle, Selling ships usually has a 3-8% loss in resale value, but honestly there's really never a reason to downgrade your ship.

The shining star for me in this game had to for sure be the writing and all the little Easter eggs left in the background. Plenty of references to scifi shows and movies got a chuckle out of me. I laughed so hard at a dialog tree in the final mission I tracked down the dev's Discord just to say thanks 😂

If you're a completionist, the $100M achievement [i]sucks[/i]. I suggest finding the most dangerous sector(s) you can that have stations, and just cycling through them looking for the $100k+ bounties. It'll take a while, but you'll get there. Oh, and don't forget to jettison the jumba beans!

author: {'steamid': '76561198326313153', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4470, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1973, 'last_played': 1697496303}
review:
Just finished the game and I loved it.  A great art style, good writing, the soundtrack is great and just a fun world to spend time in.  It's kind of crazy how deep this game goes, you can make money as a courier, you can mine asteroids, kill pirates, buy low, sell high as a cargo transporter, salvage derelict wrecks or just clear out space junk around space stations.

Tip: you can farm credits in the early game while avoiding triggering the story so you're a bit more prepared when things kick off.  No spoilers, but at some point you'll be given a ship, but won't be credited for the ship you already have, so go back to your save (save often!), sell your ship for something cheap, and once you get a free ship you'll have that cash in your account.

But yeah, a real gem of a game and the only shame is there isn't sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023709494', 'num_games_owned': 648, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 1276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1143, 'last_played': 1652877481}
review:
Gameplay: 8/10
Story: 6/10
Graphics: 7/10
Performance: 9/10 

Overall: 7/10

3030 Deathwar Redux is a solid little top-down space adventure game with very addicting gameplay. Forewarning though, 3030 Deathwar is very simplistic in both its flight model (being top down and with little control over ship systems) and missions. In further detail, the most you can really do during in-transit flight is refuel your ship if you packed extra fuel. Regarding missions, most missions are just “take this from point A to point B”. Not only that, but most missions don’t tend to pay that much, capping out at around 100,000 and those missions are often very rare. Meanwhile, a decent ship can cost you up to 6 million. Meaning you’ll be doing a lot of grinding for money and if you hate grinding then you’ll absolutely hate this game. 

Although I might come off as talking about this game negatively, there is a decent game here. While not as in-depth as other top-down space games, such as FTL or Space Rangers, what little 3030 Deathwar does it does very well. Stations are designed beautifully, each starship is distinct and there are a ton to choose from, trading is intuitive and easy, you can mine, hunt pirates, commit piracy yourself, explore derelict ships, complete transport missions, racing, participate in battles between pirates and the police, survey missions, delivery missions, taxi missions, etc., so while 3030 Deathwar isn’t as thick with content as other top down space games, what is there is still worth pursuing. 

Graphically, being a top-down space game, I wouldn’t expect much. The only issue is that many entities and ships do appear copy pasted. For example, only a handful of stations are unique in their interior and exterior appearance. Derelicts all look largely the same and even pirates/police tend to fly the exact same ships every time you encounter them. Even so, these copy-pasted textures and models are substantially detailed. Also don’t let the cartoony graphics fool you, the game can be very dark at times. For example, if you destroy a ship, you can often find bodies floating from the battle afterward, which you can collect and sell for cash. Derelict ships will contain dead bodies and sometimes pornographic magazines. Honestly something I wasn’t expecting to see, but it definitely game reason towards the included “YouTube safe” button! 

In addition to everything mentioned previously, sound design is a huge plus. With 3030 Deathwar featuring a multitude of songs most of which are designed with a sort of 80s aesthetic. Performance is also a huge plus as I rarely encountered bugs and the game is very easy to run on even the most barebones systems. Really the weakest area of 3030 Deathwar is its main story which is very confusing to follow and feels somewhat disjointed. Regardless, 3030 Deathwar is a decent little space adventure game that will keep you entertained for hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985232521', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 20, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1652414371}

Storyline is good and easy to follow and exploring the galaxy may be time consuming but rewarding. Combat is high speed at times but with the right skill you can be the ultimate pirate hunter. A brilliant hidden gem and highly recommend if you enjoy space games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006521747', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1167, 'last_played': 1651619432}
review:
Outstanding hidden gem.  I'm ashamed that I didn't find this until years after it was released.

-It has a lot of the elements of games like Escape Velocity and Endless Sky with an added ability to leave the ship and walk around spaceport bars.  

-Story is pretty funny.  It isn't heavy stuff, but it absolutely will amuse.  The writing overall is irreverent and good, if a bit light.

-There's a good abundance of ships/upgrades/weapons to choose from, but the combat in this game is a bit underwhelming.  It can still be very fun to be a bounty hunter, but it's very basic and will get repetitive.

-UI can be a bit clunky in space and buttons can't be remapped.  This doesn't stop the game from being completely functional, and after a bit of playing you'll get right in the rhythm.  

-The soundtrack absolutely slaps.  It has this 80s retro feel that will make you wanna wear sunglasses indoors while flying through space.

-The game reminds me of Curse of Monkey Island combined with that cult classic vibe from Space Rangers HD.  It is unique and amazing.  

Everyone who enjoys top down space shooters or space games in general should buy this and support devs who make original, beautiful games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002146979', 'num_games_owned': 287, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 967, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 405, 'last_played': 1652157595}

It's like the first "Civilization"  from the game "Empire" (Amiga, if anyone remembers/knows that).  Only this one is from"asteroids" to it's level of play.  Highly recommended if you want to go down memory lane.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991038022', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 999, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 999, 'last_played': 1570481983}
review:
This was a splendid space adventure! I didn't have particulary high thoughts before starting my playthrough but I was blown away by the setting, the attention to pixel-detail and the retro feel. Marveous Soundtrack by the Kyoto Connection and simple yet rewarding exploration, space travel, ship2ship combat and story. Good written characters and a nice fitting story for the style and theme.

The only major complaint is that it would have been nice if it could have lasted longer, which is exactly what my wife say about me. And we're still married, so... well. It's something.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075858196', 'num_games_owned': 757, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1309, 'last_played': 1562173867}
review: Fun adventure.  Creative setting.  Good writing.  Accessible but fairly deep combat.  Banging soundtrack.  If this had actually come out in the 90's, everyone would know it as an all time classic.  As it is, it belongs near the very top of the indie pile.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010531231', 'num_games_owned': 448, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 454, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 454, 'last_played': 1648237428}
review:
tl;dr Small space travel/fighter adventure with tons of atmosphere and a quite unique and interesting space-travel approach.

I am both fan of space trading games and retro stuff but wanted to keep my hopes low when 3030 Deathwar appeared on my radar. While it doesn't provide complexity of bigger games, ie. it's really easy to fly the spacecrafts, the fights are really arcadish, I mean, Privateer/Rebel Galaxy Outlaw are tactical space fight simulators when compared to, but it has a few things where it stands out:

1. Radios/music. They are amazing. The first missions you take (transporting people within a system), when you depart from a space station, see other ships minding their own business and you hear a song, this reminds me of long night rides with just radio on.

2. Space stations & adventure part of the game. While all space stations navigate the same, although they look differently, they are not tedious to walk through to meet other characters and sometimes you have to meet them in person to perform a given task. It's a good addition that really works. You don't have to walk for minutes to get anywhere. I wish the layouts were different sometimes, even having two separate floors where trading and job computers could be placed sometimes. Like anything to have the space stations not only look but feel different.

3. Interstellar travel. This is where the game stands out to me. The games usually go two routes:
- travel using jump points (these can be star gates, anomalies, whatever). This takes away a bit of your freedom, as you're dependent on objects that exist in certain places but it also creates routes along which the spaceships travel and this feels natural
- jump to any other star system from almost any point - this is something I quite dislike in Elite/Frontier games. when you jump into a system, you meet other ships but there's almost no reason for them to be there unless they're hunting for other pilots (or mining or travelling to other stations within a system but many systems are empty)
3030 Deathwar manages to combine both approaches and adds a bit of skill and exploration on top of that.

And this is one of the things I'd love to see in other space trading games:

See, there are nebulas between star systems. To travel safely between stars you have to avoid nebulas. Initially you have just a general map of them, you know what more or less to avoid. Later on you can buy a nebula radar which will allow you to find passages between nebulas to speed up the travel. I love this aspect of the game. I actually would love if you would have to run away from enemies to hide behind nebulas if they'd interfere with the radar system, etc.

Second thing I really like about space-travel system in 3030 Deathwar is that it mixes travel wihtin a star system and interstellar travel nicely. There's a device to perform such travel called split drive. If you engage it, you move much faster than without it. But within a star system, you're moving still at relatively low speed. When you leave it, you start to move much much faster. As space stations might be at different locations within a star system, sometimes it is a good idea to go around a star system to approach it from the other side, to enter the star system closer to your final destination.

Both of these features make space travel require a bit more thinking and makes it more exciting.

Even refuelling using fuel scoop is a bit more demanding as you have to plan ahead how much fuel you've got (although having hydrogen in your cargo doesn't hurt). In Elite: Dangerous you just jump system-to-system and when you're low on fuel, you get closer to the star. If you don't have a fuel scoop you have to plan ahead a bit, to know where is a safe place to get some fuel on the way but that's it. What's even worse is unless you use space trader tool, you won't even use longer routes usually. And space trader tool (or other tools) really break the game (unless you don't use it properly).

Trading. Haven't used it. Mined a few rocks but for most of the game, you're good with missions which get quite repetitive but that's the standard fare. I wish there are no procedurally generated missions in which you may choose what to do or that chain together with some simple stories behind them.

You are also not really encouraged to trade as you start with a space taxi and get enough money by taking people and packages to get a better ship. Then you're somehow stick to the missions as they're easy money. And then you also get significant amounts of money as you reach certain milestones. The only times I used trading computers are when I was dropping loot.

But there's much more to the game than just trading and actual fedex missions or people transport. There's the standard deal with mining but there is also looting derelicts which on its own is a minigame and also is a bit of a separate story about a mythical derelict full of gold that you might end up hunting when you finish the main story line.

You may also be a pirate but I am not sure if the game doesn't make it too easy for you by letting you into the normal stations. Only blocking them when you try to reenter them within a certain time.

Haven't yet tried to shoot people in the bar which might be possible. There are certain moments in the story where you may talk to the characters. Having an option to bring out the gun turns out really useful at times. [spoiler]I loved the climax, where you meet the villians in person and you have a total control. While I decided to talk to the first villian I met and learn as much as possible, I decided to that I will kill them last. When I stopped talking, I immediately pulled out my gun,killed them and went to the main villian. He turned around, seemingly expecting to have a chit-chat first only to meet my gun and get killed. This is something I used to hate in some of the movies, the final explosure and ability to skip it, to just wreck the final guy, feels amazing.[/spoiler].

The game is relatively short and while there is a certain amount of things to do once you finish the story, I guess that many people may already had explored the whole (small) galaxy and won't find much to do. But the few hours you get from doing the main story line are still worth both the money and your time.

And I wish to see this space-travel system implemented in more games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198305529708', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 1805, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1303, 'last_played': 1705960607}
review: This is a 2D Elite Dangerous with a story mission like if you were playing in single player mode.  It is much less complex and a more relaxing experience.  It is enjoyable and doesn't feel like a space job you have to invest in.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047965744', 'num_games_owned': 796, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 788, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 715, 'last_played': 1656258004}
review: An extremely charming game with an excellent soundtrack by the group The Kyoto Connection (H.E.A.T is the song used in the trailer). 3030 Deathwar Redux is one of those games that leaves you feeling a bit sad when it ends. I really wish there were a sequel or game set in the same universe with the adventure game aspect expanded on. I can for sure see myself getting nostalgic about 3030 Deathwar in a few years and giving it another spin.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995030737', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 576, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1644264793}
review:
Still early on in this game would wanted to give it a positive review since I was surprised it took me so long to come across it.

Great atmosphere, perfect sense of humour, solid space fun. Some of the finest storytelling I have ever seen in the opening of a game. A soundtrack that I actually enjoy listening to, it actually feels like a game made to be fun and interesting to an adult and not a cynical commercial product made for children, what an exciting concept!

Buy it now please and tell everybody who will listen, buy it! We need more games like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198917382132', 'num_games_owned': 120, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 1397, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 241, 'last_played': 1689863313}
review: Eu sou um pai de 45 anos, provavelmente uma das pessoas mais velhas a jogar este jogo. Sou pai solteiro criando meu filho, que agora tem 14 anos. Meu filho ganhou este jogo no Natal de 2021 de seu tio, então o instalamos em seu computador e ele começou a jogar. Até o final da semana ele tinha 24 horas neste jogo. Isso foi horrível para mim, pois já era difícil encontrar maneiras de passar o tempo com meu filho, pois ele está sempre com os amigos ou apenas assistindo ao YouTube. Então eu decidi fazer uma conta no Steam e pegar esse jogo para ver se eu poderia jogar ao lado dele. Eu comprei o jogo, criei meu caçador e comecei a jogar, mas eu estava preso no que você deveria fazer. Pedi ajuda ao meu filho e ele organizou um jogo para eu participar. Adorei, pois foi o melhor momento que passei com meu filho desde que minha esposa morreu. Desde então, esse jogo aproximou eu e meu filho novamente e agora passamos um tempo juntos fora de casa também. Este jogo me lembrou que há diversão em tudo, e trouxe muitas lembranças felizes para mim e meu filho.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067371366', 'num_games_owned': 2090, 'num_reviews': 584, 'playtime_forever': 1839, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1839, 'last_played': 1637063039}
review: A pleasant little surprise, this indie game! Calling it "the Elite Dangerous for the poor" would be unfair, and yet kind of true, on some aspects only. Drawn like an old side scrolling Lucas Arts, this is not a point and click but an adventure / space exploration game. The main gameplay is like in Elite and all the others of the genre, explore, do some repetitive missions like mining, taxiing, pirate hunting, get more money, buy a better ship, upgrade it, repeat. Along with that, you get lots of dialogues that are actually very well written, funny, quirky, absurd, like in an 80s B movie. You also get some sort of story driven campaign, but let us be fair, it was underwhelming (very short, abrupt ending, no plot twists...). Truthfully, they should have spent less time on some parts (like the basic NPCs dialogues or the ship upgrades) and more on this main story, which deserved better. The Galaxy is fine, but gets very repetitive. There are many ships to have, and yet as soon as I bought my 1 million ship, I realised there was no incentive for me to keep buying the other ones, it's not as if the interior of the ship changed or something - barely a bit of maneuvering. The visuals are what they are: lots of bitmaps and sprites glued to your screen! either you laugh with them or at them, but I was not bothered (it is indie and totally in the spirit of the game). Now the last thing I need to mention if you are still hesitant: if you are a music fan, buy this game... just for the music! WOW! Thank you to the devs for making me discover such amazing music artists. And especially my hats off to The Kyoto Connection, main band featured in this game, WOW, totally fits the game, the retro-futuristic feel of it, a tremendous sound! So I recommend it but I still think this game deserves more than now, maybe a sequel with more means? still a game with lots of heart put into it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052969087', 'num_games_owned': 1093, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 758, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 758, 'last_played': 1622613933}
review: My all-time favourite game. This is a thematic mix of Star Wars + Indiana Jones + Freelancer. Live the life of a space pirate by dogfighting, mining, trading, and questing. The pixel art screams Lucasarts quality and the soundtrack is phenomenal. The gameplay loop is run of the mill: quest for gold and upgrade your ships and repeat. The best part is the atmosphere. Some days I just launch this game and fly around listening to the awesome soundtrack. The controls, space maps, and radar navigation takes some getting used to.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013321186', 'num_games_owned': 261, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 1112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1112, 'last_played': 1625199010}
review:
[h1] 3030 Deathwar Redux [/h1] 

[b] The Good [/b]
[list] 
[*]	Ships all feel different from each other which is pretty cool, helping you to weigh your options 
[*]	Ship combat is frantic and fun reminiscent of old arcade shooters 
[*]	There is a ton of personality in its art style form neon lights space stations to various design of space ships to the unusual and quirky citizens that live in this place 
[*]	There are quite a number of things to do which is quite impressive, mining, pirate hunting, taxi jobs, delivery, photography jobs 
[*]	Dialogue is often entertaining and quirky 
[*]	Music is really good having synthwaves like music during the space shootouts and exploring space. There is also quite a lot of musical tracks and variety 
[/list]

[b] The Bad [/b]
[list]
[*]	While there is variety, sadly there is limitation in its systems. The same areas are often used in salvaging missions. Most space stations although have unique personality is essentially the same layout. 
[*]      Repetitive game design, the ship combat starts to be a repeat of the same old especially in the late game. 
[*]	Variety in locations only start if you follow the main storyline 
[*]	A lot of info dump at the start
[*]	Humor is not for everyone though 
[/list]

[h1] Summary [/h1]

[b] Gameplay 6 - [/b] Its a fun open world space simulator with some fun top down action. Its impressive what they have did in terms of offering variety of missions and jobs as well as some light puzzle adventure moments. Sadly it is hindered by repetitive game design in the late stages and side content. 

[b] Graphics 5 - [/b] While its nothing to shout about, it oozes a lot of personality and each ship and quirky denizens of the galaxy do feel very distinct 

[b] Sound 7 - [/b] The music and sound effects in this game is quite good giving you a ton of variety. From synthwave beats, to some quirky cantina music reminiscent of star wars cantina music with its own unique flavour. The variety in musical tracks is quite amazing making the journey of exploring this quirky galaxy quite relaxing at times.

[b] Story 6 - [/b] While there is nothing new about this cliche absurd sci fi adventure, it still has quite a lot to offer in terms of humor and bizzare but overall entertaining writing. Although in my opinion the humor is not for everyone    

[h1] The Review [/h1] 

If there is one thing to be said about 3030 Deathwar redux, its definitely, quirky, unusual but surprisingly fun to go around this bonkers galaxy. 3030 Deathwar redux is made by developer Bird in the Sky. This 10 year project honestly brims with personality despite some quirks and flaws in this rogue-lite space shooting adventure.

The games starts as you, John Falcon and his crew finds a dead body on his newly acquired ship after a salvaging gig. On returning to the closest space port to find answers, he and his crew soon finds out they are in bigger trouble. John new ship is impounded as stolen, his crew members have to be let go for the time being, while he is stuck on a measly dingy space ship looking for work. Here the game leaves you to your own devices to either follow the bizarre mildly absurd comedic premise or go around and literally do your own thing making it a pretty interesting space simulator as well. There is not much handholding when it comes to the basic tutorial as it explains what you need and just leaves you at the airlock to fumble along. I did wish that they did a better way of introducing the mechanics of the game because for the first hour, I was bombarded with all sort of information and was pretty lost.

But once I figured out how to use the maps properly and the various computer consoles to get jobs, upgrades or sell merchandise and cargo, the game starts to open up. Deathwar 3030 redux requires quite a bit of experimentation to get the hang of things from salvaging, mining, being a space taxi driver, bounty hunter, pirate hunter, photographer and even a space cleaning garbage men. It controls well enough with its variety of ships taking a book from other top down arcade shooters. Controlling with basic WASD and spacebar to shoot. For the most part the game does not really throw a barrage of bullet hell moments, instead it eases you slowly into this bonkers adventure and music of this absurd galaxy. Although at times combat can be pretty frantic with a few bullet hell moments which can be pretty fun. There is also a ton of ships to experiment. Ship variety is plentiful and adds some depth. For example bigger ships usually benefit in bringing more cargo but are difficult to maneuver in a combat situation where as small fighter are quick and nimble but can only bring a small cargo. 

There are other things added as well. Away from the top down space action moments, you can explore derelict ships for salvage with you floating around with your radar that locates loot and cargo. However this side scrolling salvaging areas always feel the same and becomes remarkably repetitive in the game with the same layouts as well as enemies. This really puts me off into salvaging any derelicts. With that being said, what I find impressive is the way Deathwar adds variety to the simple top down action gameplay. Taxi and delivery missions are added timers which add some depth as you contemplate which ship have enough cabin space or a thruster to get you fast enough to that location. Same as garbage disposal. Although these mechanics are not new and have been done before, it’s a nice addition to the simple top down action gameplay which takes a large portion of the time.  

3030 Deathwar redux continuously throws all sort of random moments and things at you letting you experience the absurd cliché moments of the game through its quirky writing. However the humor is a bit of hit and miss. It’s not for everyone, with John sarcastic replies and the denizen’s goofy banter but it overall works for me. It does have a very Lucas arts adventure feel of old as you move around the pixelated environment and talk to all sorts of characters when you are out of your ship. The pixelated graphics although not impressive definitely has a lot of personality with its neon light space stations, goofy bars, and bizarre funny alien design. The music is another bonus with its often entertaining synthwave bliss tracks and cantina music which differs from space station to combat to exploration. I was surprise at the amount of musical tracks that this game has as it kept the mood always interesting.  Sadly the game illusion starts to falter in the later stages as you realize the combat never changes much, most of the space stations have the same layout with some nice visual designs to differentiate from the rest, and salvaging is remarkably repetitive. It’s also kind of a miss opportunity the developer did not go further with playing around with the point click adventure moments with more puzzles which could have even added more variety. 

However it is commendable what the developers have done, giving you a wide variety of things to do with the limitations they have. This game does brim with a lot of passion. The humour may not be for everyone but for RM 30 which is roughly 7 USD, this budget indy space simulator/ adventure game does offer quite a bit of content and replay value for your money's worth if you can look past some of its flaws.

author: {'steamid': '76561198287475338', 'num_games_owned': 111, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 1724, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1724, 'last_played': 1620999095}
review:
3030 Deathwar Redux - A Space Odyssey is this:
-a top down, pixel art 2D shooter cum adventure game, with emphasis on the shooter part.(space is actually in 3D)
-multiple save slots, save any time while on  stations, autosaves available too.
-player controls single ship, many new ships for trade in, ship is upgrade-able with many parts, weapons is combination of one turret plus a front mounted gun as the main attack, missiles and homing mines as sub attack.
-adventure story happens mostly while on stations, specifically in the bars of the station.
-has simple mining, tractor beam for cargo and people, and a mini game called derelict ship looting.
-No dynamic economy.

The music of this game just blew me away. They are not the original soundtracks of this game, just some music and songs under the Creative Commons license. One of the band responsible for the captivating songs in this game is called The Kyoto Connection, they are a band from Argentina. The album is called No Headphones Required . And there was another great musician responsible for the adventure music called Kevin MacLeod. Whoever decided to use their music, you are the real mvp of this game. 

The space combat is nicely done. A bit to the easy side but that is exactly what I liked because I have slow fingers. Pew pew pew. The character art is quite detailed , especially those small items, whoever did that is very perceptive artist. The weakest link of the chain is actually the story, it is short, a bit lackluster  , and not enough presence of female characters involved(sigh was hoping to see some romance plots). I got the second best ship of the game, but the story can be finish in about 25 hours if you don't want to grind for  the better ships and better weapons. All in all a great experience.

Edit: Now for those interested in the same genre, you might want to give Starsector a shot (it is a fleet combat game, you still control one ship directly but the 30 ships following you around is still too much for me). It is not on steam yet. For steam games you might like Gaia Beyond and Starcom Nexus. I was playing Gaia Beyond and I think it is far prettier than any other top-down space shooters on steam right now. There is a game called Endless Sky which I heard is a total legend so you might want to check it out too, it is free by the way. And there is Space Pirates and Zombies, it is a dated game so it looks a bit ugly to me but you might like it. I tried Star Valor, but dislike its implementation of ship ability and perks being unlocked only after your death, it is a mechanic used by roguelike genre to keep you from experiencing the whole game from the get go, by locking important game content behind "death wall" so to speak.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968469448', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 5634, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2145, 'last_played': 1620949319}
review:
Played a few hours now and really enjoy the simplicity of the game and the nostalgia it has.

Highlights:
Music - Very unique, kind of reminds me of Cowbow Bepop.  Not the same, but reminds me of it.
Story - I am enjoying the story so far.  Simple, with some surprises and so far keeping it entertaining.
Dialogue - Others have mentioned cliche dialogue which is an unfair review.  This was the intent, and it works.  Of course it's cliche, but a couple of times I have chuckled.  If you are expecting serious writing, move on.  If you go watch a Godzilla movie, and you are mad giant monsters are in the movie, then that is on you!
Ship Combat - It's simple pew pew, yet still fun to upgrade your ship and blow stuff up.  I like complicated simulations, but sometimes I just want to pew pew.

Lowlights
- None yet really.  I wasn't expecting much from the game and it sort of hooked me, which I found surprising.  Will update if I think of any.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046125007', 'num_games_owned': 480, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 1860, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1860, 'last_played': 1619701878}
review: Would recommend but only if you really like point&click INSPIRED pixel games with privateer genre elements (space travel, salvage ships for cargo, selling said cargo and fighting pirates. The privateer parts of the game are well made into a cohesive whole, although the missions are a bit repetitive after a while. But because they are auto generated you will have fun for a long time. The other part, the point&click part of the game is a bit disappointing. Especially since it looks a little like a Lucasarts game. There are few original scenes, most of them are repetitive space stations and salvage ships backgrounds. Nothing like point&click games we grew up with like The Dig, or Full throttle. No truly memorable characters. The game protagonist is a meld of different characters we loved as children but he doesn't offer a unique memorable experience. If you really like pixel point&click games and want to experience everything, then you can buy this on a sale, but if you can spare your time for only the fine things in life then I would recommend some of the older pixel point&click games, maybe some of the new games, like Deponia or A new begining - final cut.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021078112', 'num_games_owned': 922, 'num_reviews': 184, 'playtime_forever': 1668, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1668, 'last_played': 1619379533}
review: Неуклюжая попытка сделать мультижанровую игру. Заполненная всякими интересными мелочами, но пустая в ядре игра. Все элементы там в итоге ужасные. Симулятор курьера в космосе с недопиксельной графикой, в смысле тупо надерганные какие-то непонятные фотки/рендеры в низком разрешении, стилистически смотрящиеся отвратительно. Персонажи нарисованы, но без особого старания. Сюжет уровня школьных фанфиков, полёты унылые, активности тем более, оружие особо друг от друга не отличается, платформенная часть вообще до смеха примитивная. И понтовая попсятина, играющая в космосе... Реально смысл смотреть на такое - только как пример дикой кустарной самодеятельности, когда создатели сидят на своей волне и остальной мир не замечают.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968187165', 'num_games_owned': 755, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 508, 'last_played': 1616936389}
review:
英語が読めてストーリーに沿って1本道プレイのみで続ければ佳作ぐらいの出来のゲーム
インディ・ジョーンズの格好をしたハン・ソロみたいな主人公がブレードランナーみたいな世界でひょんな事からいざこざに巻き込まれて対処しているうちに銀河を救うとか言う感じの話だと思う多分
ゲーム性はがばがば他の外人のレビュー通りせっていがばがばで3万の初期船から違いが感じられるのが
何百回もお使いをしないと手に入らない300万の船しかないという感じの設定
ミッションも5種類ぐらいあるけどTAXIはステーションに行くだけ 宅配はTaxiにひと手間ふえてステーションに行って中にいる客に話しかけるだけ ゴミ掃除はそこらに漂っているちっさい浮遊物を打つだけ バウンティはあんまりやる気のない海賊属性がついているだけの一般船みたいのを探して倒すだけ といろいろあるけどどれもやりたくないのから好きなのを選べますよという感じのなんとも言えない品揃え
エリートデンジャラスは未プレイだけどエリートデンジャラスがこんなスカスカゲーだったらDLCは１つも販売できていないはず
Spazはプレイ済みだがSpazはすかすかだけゲーム性はここまでがばがばではない
曲やグラとステーションの汚いコンソールの出来は良いのでゲーム性を追求しない人にはいいかも

author: {'steamid': '76561197985654160', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 408, 'playtime_forever': 63, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1613406552}
review:
Eine Adventure-Space-Sim, was richtig Spaß macht. Die "Hauptstory" (?) hab ich jetzt nicht so verfolgt, aber das Aufträge erfüllen, durch die Galaxies cruzen und Geld verdienen um bessere Schiffe und Upgrades zu erhalten motiviert und macht Freude. Die Grafik ist sehr charmant und liebevoll gemacht. Die Stationssequenzen fühlen sich ein bisschen wie die alten Point-and-Clicks an nur ohne Point-and-Click, man bewegt sich flüssig, aber es fühlt sich halt so an - was ich Positiv meine. Die Weltall-Sequenzen laufen von der "Vogelperspektive", das Raumschiff driftet und gleitet, dass es eine wahre Freude ist.

Hier der Link zu meinem "Angespielt"-Video:
https://youtu.be/Q9lm846WsjE

author: {'steamid': '76561198025813626', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3010, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3010, 'last_played': 1596816354}
review:
God damn I loved this game.
I wish it could go on forever.

Combine the best parts of every 2D space game you have ever played and add some Neo- Japanese cultural revolution plus some acid and you get this.

Soundtrack alone was worth every cent, the gameplay was fast and loose, plenty of tactical 2d space pewpew without getting overly technical. Ships get stronger but never so much that you're ever completely safe. Crash a deathbowl and you will soon see what i mean...

I will admit to spending way too much time squashing bugs....

the story is easy to follow, perhaps a little too easy at times, and although extremely interesting it does have a solid foot in the "linear" side of things. This is not so much a criticism as it is a diehard player begging for (much) more of the same. Spent over 50 hours and it still felt too short.

Did i mention I fucking love this game, yes i believe i did

author: {'steamid': '76561198003174259', 'num_games_owned': 1741, 'num_reviews': 317, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1529945204}
review:
[h1] The Simplicity of Space [/h1]

[b] What I Liked [/b]

I recommend this game as a decent, affordable, space shooter.  It's not the best space shooter I have played, nor is it the worst.  It's simplistic.  So why am I recommending it?  Because I think it's a good game for what it's trying to do, especially for the price point.  I purchased it on sale and don't regret supporting the developer.  If it's on sale, I'd say give it a try.  You may end up liking it.  If you breeze through the story in the beginning of the game, you can try out the combat before the 2 hour mark so you can get a refund if you really don't think it's for you.

[b] What I Did Not Like [/b]

I am someone who likes complicated systems when it comes to designing a ship.  While this one does have different ways to upgrade your ship, I didn't find it fulfilling enough.  It also had a mix of click-based story telling.  Those aren't my strong suit,

[b] Why I Stopped Playing [/b]

I made multiple purchases during a sale that was happening, including this game, so I moved on to another game I had purchased.  I doubt I will re-visit this game unless I want a simple space shooter with text-based story telling.

[b] Disclaimer [/b]

I have been a gamer for over 30 years.  I tend to play mostly PC games.  I also bounce around between games A LOT.  I may purchase a $60 game and play it for 2 hours or spend $10 on a game and spend 50 hours on it.  Even if I played a game a short time, it does not mean it is bad.  It just means another game caught my attention.  I also complain about flaws in games a lot, even about the littlest of things.  Keep that in mind when reading my reviews.  If I do not have a complaint, then the game must be special!

review:
Dialogues, descriptions of people and ships are hilarious. Humor is a big plus of this game and it keeps a not so serious atmosphere. I wish AAA games had at least half of it.
Flying a ship with upgrades and the spacefights are also cool. At the end you'll feel like a pro, switching the background maps while speeding through a star system, requesting landing on a station and evading the enemies at the same time. Although the jobs on the stations are repetitive after a while, main plot is still entertaining. I wouldn't trade this for something like Elite: Dangerous.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979908184', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 1698, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1219, 'last_played': 1600655772}
review:
Worth buying. A true labor of love game. This game really shows its indie passion project roots. It has a unique flavor and look that really could only come out of the vision and effort of a small independent team working for years like this one. The game has continued to get updates for some time after release up to the time of this review which is another positive sign for the game and the development team behind it. The content they've added over time has expanded the game well. 

The graphics are charming 2D pixel art work with a lot of variety and fun. Controls are pretty good and the combat as a result is fun and easy to get into, with a good variety of weapons, ships, mods and stuff to keep it from getting boring. The developers have included a fun story to follow, mostly at your own pace, along with open sandbox play to explore and enjoy - trading, piracy, hunting outlaws, races, mining asteroids, and so on all to make a profit and explore the galaxy.

If you like any of the classic top down space trading and adventure games you'll likely enjoy this. It has the feel of a good space game crossed with a touch of Firefly and a classic Lucasarts or Sierra adventure game. There are a few touches I won't spoil that show the kind of fun and love the developers have for their game. 

The music is surprisingly above par with a lot of good quality music tracks included. 

At the budget price the developers set the game at it is well worth it and you'll get your money's worth of entertainment out of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981532595', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 2089, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2089, 'last_played': 1598984552}
review:
Es ist.... seltsam. Man nehme ein sehr schlichtes Adventure Game, kombiniere dies mit einem primitiven  Raumschiff-Arcade-Shooter, einen Bergungs-Simulator mit furchtbar wenig Tiefgang, klebe eine extrem simple Wirtschaftssimulation dran, bette das alles in einem wenig abwechslungsreichen Universum ein und vollende das alles mit einem klischeehaften Plot und einem irgendwie billigen Grafikdesign... 

Aber verdammt, während jeder Teil für sich allein mich wenig angesprochen hätte, hat die Art und Weise, wie es zusammengewürfelt worden ist etwas ergeben, das sich über die Summe der Einzelteile mehr als erheben konnte. Ernsthaft, als ich dies das erste Mal gesehen habe, dachte ich mir "was um Himmels Willen soll das sein?". Aber da wars im Sale, und irgendwie war mir langweilig, und ... nun ja.

Irgendwie schaffte es die oben beschriebene Kombination, mich erstaunlich 34 Stunden lang am Bildschirm festzuhalten. Es gibt Tripple A Titel aus großen Softwareschmieden, die ich nicht so fetzig fand! Wenn mich jemand fragen würde "was findest du besser, No Mans Sky oder 3030 Deathwar?" würde ich ohne zu zögern für Deathwar stimmen. Nein, ich wurde nicht von irgendjemanden bestochen ;)

Also, wenn etwas Entspanntes sucht, um euer Bedürfnis nach Sci-Fi Adventures zu befrieden, das sich eher wie 90er Jahre B-Movie als wie ein Spiel anfühlt, dann greift zu! 
Irgendwie schade, dass es wohl kaum mal eine Fortsetzung geben dürfte...

author: {'steamid': '76561198023757658', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 3604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1848, 'last_played': 1665870681}
review:
This is a fun little light at heart game. I enjoy the simplicity.  A lot of the characters  are used a bit too much, so when you travel for hundreds of AU's, you see the same folks at the bar.  Other than that, I enjoyed it for the time I've play thus far ...especially the music..... however after a deeper playthrough, this game is really a light sim that needs balanced. Here are a few of my complaints::

1) - There is no reason to explore derelict ships other than the first few you encounter. They are all the same in all the star systems.

2) - Mining asteroids is extremely unprofitable and a waste of time unless you are really into doing so. You get constantly interrupted by NPC's offering to protect you or buy your ores to the point that you get little done. 

3) - The best ways for making money and using your time is in completing taxi missions or hunting pirates.  

The Honest Truth:  If it wasn't for the great music in this game, I may not have ever played it for so long as I have. It's really a "One & Done" type of game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198099012387', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 2508, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2106, 'last_played': 1598642609}
review:
As an indie game, it is pretty light on depth and technical execution anywhere you look, although it has a surprisingly deep and thoughtfully constructed ship pool. Than's not to say it's janky, mind. As a videogame/software package, it's competently put together. 

Despite the indie-esque depth problems, it manages to successfully check most every major box necessary for a space-trading game. It has pretty much everything you would expect from one of these games. It is a true-blue successful entry in the genre, if a minor one. What its various bits and pieces lack in oomph, it makes up for in charm and clever development, a wry and prevailing sense of humour, and being 100% in tune with the genre.

Mechanically speaking, in space it's basically Asteroids, on stations it's basically old Lucasarts. Each side is done pretty well. It has a fairly lengthy progression system in place via ship upgrades, but it's not something you would consider an RPG-style mechanic as the whole thing is pretty much oriented towards opening doors and then making your ship better. There are only two consumables complexifying that stairway that I've encountered, one being missiles, and the other being a shield recharge.

It has a pretty interesting story and handles pacing and characters pretty well.

If I had any criticism for the game, it would be that the trading is a little weak. This is something that a lot of the games in the genre have trouble with though; which is somewhat ironic when you consider that a genre half-named for a particular mechanic would have it be one that it so frequently underserves. 

The game generally sets up systems to have buy/sell relationships with other systems in their vicinity, but the profits are usually lowball. There are higher-value commodities, but these are in very short supply and are mostly relevant to the salvaging mechanic. There are a couple of those higher-tier commodities that can be bought in limited quantities in various places and held on to before selling at a particular place that buys them very high, and this will generally net the best profits per sell, but it does take a significant amount of time. 

Also, there is a supply-and-demand mechanic in the game which will alter these prices across sessions; that mechanic is nothing I would consider additive, though, given the time it takes to make a full sell of the better cargoes. The trading system is also fairly opaque with almost no mechanisms to demystify it and nothing to gain current price information remotely, with basically only trial-and-error and then some best-guessing as tools to succeed. It all adds up to a mechanic that is somewhat underwhelming.

Trading is not a total wash, though. I found a couple of nice 3-point routes, including one where you couldn't refuel in the middle system, thereby adding a bit of extra interest. You can combine the mission board with trading very well (which is something not even the big players in the genre manage to do as well as this game), and when so done, the profits are relevant to timely progression.

You won't get a tenth as much time out of this as you will from the old standbys of this genre, but what you will get is funny, 100% authentic to the genre, and enjoyable, and then you'll have some time to for the love of god play something else once in a while.

Some of the non-game music may make you want to kill yourself. Watch out for that.

You may start liking that music. Double watch out for that.

Really lo-fi but really good.

If you need to be wowed, stay away, but if you don't mind indie games, and you really like this genre, you could really like the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068552371', 'num_games_owned': 685, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 2194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2194, 'last_played': 1593786927}
review:
Космосим очень даже неплохой, пострелушка приятная на вид, правда прицел можно было бы сделать настраиваемым в плане цвета хотя бы (либо это есть и я в глаза долблюсь). Музыкальное сопровождение прям вах, одно из самых хороших вещей в игре. Гринда какого-либо нет, на хороший корабль можно быстро заработать добычей руды или например охотой на пиратов по квестам (могут по >100к давать). Проходняк на раз или два - сойдёт. Концовка, скажу так, была слишком неожиданной (в плане как всё быстро и легко закончилось) :D
P.S. от музыки на станциях флешбеки после игр Акабура

author: {'steamid': '76561198052351321', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 3997, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3997, 'last_played': 1591696960}
review:
In the end you save the galaxy and immidiately after that you get attacked by pirates. So typical. Well, this game is remotely comparable to Rebel Galaxy... in 2D... pixel graphics. The big difference for me is, that Rebel Galaxy is one of the few games in my 50 years of life, that I re-played. 4 times btw.
However, 3030 Deathwar was nice to play through, 60 hours of fun involved, no regrets. Dear developers, thank you for a good time!

review: I liked this game. I didn't love it and I didn't feel motivated to do much beyond the minimum to complete the story but it had its charm. I think for another person it could really speak to them but it just didn't quite land for me. It is pleasantly silly and it does a decent job of setting up some interesting characters. I love the graphics and there has clearly been a lot of love put into it. Still, merely average for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983234693', 'num_games_owned': 1364, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 675, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 360, 'last_played': 1590430143}

author: {'steamid': '76561198010679705', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 605, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 605, 'last_played': 1588472210}
review:
A very rough and unpolished gem but so much potential to be more.  Arcade-style combat and exploration similar to Star Control 2 with Elite style missions of trading and combat.  UI needs some severe polish, controls are super janky, dialogue could be better written, and characters (outside of Kent the Robot) need some additional development. As it stands, all characters basically talk and act the same.

Still, they have the framework for what could be an excellent game next go around.  I'll be following this developer very closely to see what they come up with next.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965483513', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 2264, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2264, 'last_played': 1589940269}
review:
Overall; 3/5
Paid $7.50 about right
34 hours of completionism, 3 hours of story.

In the end I only 'liked' this.  I think the shortness of the story was a let down, given I high hopes for it at the start of the game.  Everything felt a little under developed, the UI took some getting used to (it was functional but not well designed) .  I think it had the potential to be much better with an expanded story.  I guess the developers made this as a hobby, not working full time of it. 

It is the gameplay is a mix of  the old 'Space Flight' and 'Frontier: Elite 2' with a short adventure game story stuck on. The adventure game was a very bland aspect of it overall, but I had fun mapping the nebula and doing courier missions.  (10 year old me would of loved how much easy this was than Frontier)

I had fun while playing it, but I would recommend checking out some gameplay footage before purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992570638', 'num_games_owned': 1437, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1691, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1649, 'last_played': 1591922657}
review:
Very fun 2D space combat exploration trading game similar to Privateer and other classics like Solar Winds, with a very pleasant early Lucasarts adventure games aesthetic. It’s an open-world game with a main campaign and loads of side missions, and you can really pick several different paths to progress the game, or, preferably, get an all-rounder ship with a turret and do everything, which is usually more fun anyway.

The graphics are delightfully old school and the soundtrack is simply amazing. The game is very atmospheric and the ships feel and handle very differently. The controls are tight, and there’s a very short learning curve. If you have played any space game before, this will be easy to get into.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071878410', 'num_games_owned': 643, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 705, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 468, 'last_played': 1590961723}
review:
Basicly Monkey Island... in space. 

I greatly appreciate all the witty lines that went into this. It's really well done. Takes a while to get into the game and i do feel that grinding money is so far a little slow, but it's epic and massive. A lot of love went into making this i bet.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064238450', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1209, 'last_played': 1687540473}

Great sound track. 
Plenty of story. 
Plenty of non-story things to do. 
Adventure game sequences...
Brilliant. 
Every bit deserving of 'Game of the Decade'.
