author: {'steamid': '76561198045381877', 'num_games_owned': 557, 'num_reviews': 2587, 'playtime_forever': 125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1588375663}
review:
3030 Deathwar Redux - A Space Odyssey. Never heard of this before the free weekend but I liked what I saw. I do not have a lot of time to really delve into the game in the time allotted, but I think that its definitely worth looking into if you are interested based on what I had time to play and see.  I am going to play it a little more before moving on this weekend but I am glad I got the chance to check it out. 

The art is what struck me the most, being retro and detailed in a very low sci-fi way I do not often see.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020674465', 'num_games_owned': 596, 'num_reviews': 167, 'playtime_forever': 38, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1588349201}
review:
Estamos ante una aventura diferente, combina el mundo abierto de una aventura espacial, con gestión de nave, navegación y recurso propio de otro tipo de juegos de gestión y estrategia, con una aventura grafia al mas puro estilo Lucas stars, que hará las delicias de los amantes del genero, y quien añoramos ese tipo de juegos.

Es un juego lleno de secretos, con un gran mundo interior, e ideal para los amantes de la exploración.

Es uno de esos juegos no muy conocidos para el publico general, que pueden converirse en obras de culto.

Buen diseño, y arte de los escenarios, y todo en general,y buena banda sonora.

Aprovecha, y pruebalo estos días.

Nota; 7/10.

Se agradeceria una traducción al español.

author: {'steamid': '76561198352276438', 'num_games_owned': 195, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1531, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1531, 'last_played': 1586086346}
review:
It's a [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_flight_simulation_game#Space_trading_and_combat_game]Space Cowboy game[/url], with most of the usual irritations avoided and the core mechanics done well:[list]
[*]Despite its 16-bit graphical style, the spaceflight and navigation overlays are really intuitive. Makes inter-system travel and dodging bothersome nebulae a joy. 
[*]Trading mechanics are supremely simple, and it's always made clear when you're getting a good deal.
[*]You can buy and sell ships at nearly full price. Which is awesome, because it means you can switch between being a full-fledged trader, bounty hunter, pirate, delivery boy, etc. on a whim.[/list]

The story is... well it's basically just some old LucasArts-esque nonsense. Kind of a nice comedic tone, but really just background for your highjinks in space. I do love the grimy, seedy feel of the setting though, high tech space computers with bugs crawling around on them. Lots of aphids in particular, this future galaxy seems so overrun with them that you'll get numerous achievements for helping out with a little population control.

The real masterstroke of the game is the use of the music by [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZSTs1SM46mA&list=PLoBi9S4En2T7DrISxxN5Xp_n-krZPdV7f&index=2]The Kyoto Connection[/url] whenever you're in open space. As well as creating a perfect sort of 80s space-age atmosphere, it's got a real emotivity and urgency to it, which contrasts beautifully with the silliness within the stations. As soon as the space you're in gets bigger, so seemingly do the stakes!

author: {'steamid': '76561198149975631', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 904, 'last_played': 1676511421}

author: {'steamid': '76561198369273079', 'num_games_owned': 223, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1988, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1988, 'last_played': 1586850992}
review:
I generally like Space Sims, but where 3030 Deathwar really stands out is that 1) Combat is actually fun.  The fact that you can make tactical FTL hops to get out of crossfire or set up an attack run adds a surprising amount of depth.  2) the soundtrack is excellent and matches the aesthetic really well.  I've seen numerous other people comment on this as well, but this is like maybe the 2nd game ever where i went to go look for the music to listen to out of the game.  (1 was Chrono Trigger).

Overall, well worth the cost.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010967870', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 1832, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1160, 'last_played': 1594335554}
review:
vale a pena comprar esse jogo, vale o tempo e dinheiro! no espaço vc pode explorar as naves, fazer trabalhos para ganhar dinheiro, pode lutar contra piratas e ter seu proprio nave...é o jogo de espaço que eu queria!

esse jogo é de qualidade alta! apesar de ter gráficos "antigos" mas o Conteúdo de 3030 deathwar redux é incrivel! finalmente eu estava procurando um jogo de espaço, achei esse jogo! otimo compra para meu aniversário.

atualização: eu zerei modo historia e espero um dia que tenha mais um sequência de esse jogo épico eu amo isso, sempre quis o jogo de espaço quando vc zera o jogo mas ainda tem coisas para fazer, só que fica com vontade de continuar mais na historia e ter mais opções, enfim eu recomendo o jogo!

author: {'steamid': '76561198298843563', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 5847, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5845, 'last_played': 1634580792}
review: This was one of my first games I bought full price, played and downloaded off of Steam and truly enjoyed it.  Many sleepless nights but still worth every minute of it.  And the soundtrack by The Kyoto Connection (so good, I bought many of the songs on Itunes)..dang..it was so soothing and wonderful.  I liked the open sandbox this game had because I didn't have to follow the story line before leveling.  I literally did the first 3 or 4 quests within the Andini Solar System and then just kept on doing all the other money making repeatable quests until I was able to buy one of the best fighter ships and just explored the whole map before I went back to play the actual story line.  Like some others, I know I didn't get all the achievements my first time playing, but dang, I played for hours and hours of grinding..I got the 100,000,000 achievement before I even got to the 2nd phase of the game.  That's how much grinding I did, but I enjoyed every minute of it.  Didn't use any mods.  Anyway, ever since this game, I have been looking for any other games that are similar and I haven't found any.  I also love the 80's theme..I couldn't recommend this game enough.  I hardly write any reviews, so apologies for my rant.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965197708', 'num_games_owned': 994, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 731, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 731, 'last_played': 1580191828}
review:
The game is so much better than advertised. Honestly, this is one of the best hidden gems I've ever come across.

Criticisms? The game could use some more end-game content after completing the main story line. But honestly, it should take you long enough to get there, that it's not really a huge deal.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973082193', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 864, 'last_played': 1586344876}
review:
I like the game, but it was frustrating on how little guidance you are given to start. I completely missed out on the Largo event because I had no idea it was in the initial system and I was expecting the quest to continue. But since I was not actively scavenging the initial system and there were no updates to the quest until Kent told me to come see him, I never got to salvage the gold.

However I did manage to do the Kessel run once I found it existed in the OTHER section in the menu. I've also found that mining asteroids in P1257+12 makes money a lot faster than missions.

To sum up, it's a really fun game that is sometimes also frustrating. It is a little too much like Elite in that you are basically handed a ship and told to go forth with little guidance. I would give it a 7 on a 10 scale.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961827905', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 1164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1664314341}

author: {'steamid': '76561198004594294', 'num_games_owned': 1774, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 1431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1431, 'last_played': 1585775593}
review:
I'm a 1980s kid. I recognize many of the games that influenced this, but I did not play them myself. I've been catching up in the modern era. 3030 Deathwar is one of the best space games I have played.

Admittedly, it's not perfect. Procedural station missions are where the bulk of the money is made, but they don't seem to take the stats of one's current ship into account.  For instance, cargo space never matters outside of holding extra fuel and the destination range doesn't seem to extend with ship speed. Meanwhile, there's a limit of 4 simultaneous missions so it's never made up for in bulk. Fortunately, the ship/upgrade prices are balanced such that the grind isn't excessive. It just makes the ships feel less rewarding.

Outside of stations, mining seemed nigh useless even with sensors and trading felt like too much manual tracking. Salvaging, however, at least provided a distraction and allowed items like nebula sector maps to found. All three of these activities give a reason to actually have that cargo space if you're interested.

The flying is fun. Momentum and turn rate are considered.  There's obstacles to avoid, debris to shoot, and ship traffic for you to use your best judgement on. Dogfighting can be performed with a front-facing gun and/or a turret while split engines double as quick dodges.

The campaign is light, but enjoyable. The jokes, thankfully, are not as full of pop culture references as the visual art of the NPC species wandering the galaxy. (Don't worry about those Steam workshop ship mods breaking immersion.) I spent about 20 hours. There is no real replay value. However, it is possible to continue playing in the open world once the story has ended. I bought a ship just under the highest tier, flew it out of the station, and closed the program in high spirits.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966457753', 'num_games_owned': 184, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1585795889}
review: Solid space game, definitely get on sale if you can. At first, was a tad put off by all of the grinding delivery style quests. The game really starts to build story, humor and progression. Ship upgrades, trading, mining, bounty hunting, tractor beam all sorts of things. Space travel and unlock new systems. Good things to see here in this space Freelancer style game. At first glance you may not be impressed, but give it some time and everything will delight.

author: {'steamid': '76561198280626262', 'num_games_owned': 8, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 321, 'last_played': 1587265096}
review:
Absolutely amazing game! Firstly, I want to start by saying my favorite game of all time is Starflight for the Sega genesis. 
With that out of the way, I highly recommend this game, as it was recommended to me by Space Game Junkie aka Brian.
This game has a lot of depth, and its laced with satire humour. Which makes it very unique in its own right. The music is great, i rate this game a full 10/10.

P.S.If you love space ship games, i also highly recommend you check out Space game Junkie steam page as there is some great games listed there. Personally i only like 2D space ship games, so if that resonates with you, BUY THIS GAME ITS WORTH EVERY CENT! It was 10 years in the making, and the creators obviously have pretty wild imaginative minds lolol

author: {'steamid': '76561197970967930', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 334, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 333, 'last_played': 1673694840}
review: This was a mish-mash of things old and new for someone who's played games since the 90's and I find it very amusing, if a tiny touch repetative at times due to some mechanics simplistic nature. A solid game none the less, just not quite as spectacular as it had potential to be.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065623466', 'num_games_owned': 157, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 3204, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1993, 'last_played': 1694039764}
review:
I really hate to use the phrase, but this game makes you feel like a spaceship pilot.

I don't mean flying everywhere, spamming lasers at everything until the area's clear. What I mean is  thinking about your actions, resources, and goals. Do you have enough fuel? Should I save for a better ship? Would using a missile to kill this pirate cost me more than the bounty I would get? You might be considering options such as "If I chase after this wanted space pirate for their bounty, I can still sell the cargo I purchased at this station, but I'll need to navigate around nebula clouds to reach the system."

There is a story that works as a very functional tutorial without forcing the player to follow a very strict path. You can be a trader, derelict ship salvager, bounty hunter, pirate, ore miner, cargo deliveryman, taxi, or many of the above. You can, and likely will, multitask and switch as often as you like.

Movement and navigation is easy to learn and satisfying to master. Even the basic and most cautious movement will get you where you need to go. However, everything above that will make your flying better, your travel more efficient, your battles more strategic, and you feeling like a spaceship flying master.

The gripes I have are mostly with the game's style. The visuals' low-res style rarely benefit from the pixelation, and sometimes make things look homogeneous, due to a lack of small details. The music during flight is absolutely amazing, but the music within stations is boring and often unfitting.

Nevertheless, this is one of the best games I've played, and it truly fulfills the dreams of flying a futuristic spaceship and doing what you want.

-Edit 10/27/2020: General polish, grammatical fixes, and a conclusion added.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136394698', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 956, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 956, 'last_played': 1545999429}

author: {'steamid': '76561197966792980', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 686, 'last_played': 1584586336}
review:
Hey what do you know, a snarky throwback retro game with spaceships to shoot, derelicts to ransack, trash to shoot, planets to explore and junk to sell all over the place as you drive your pixels across the stars. 

Honestly I was looking for a stupid simple game I could waste time with occasionally without investing serious brain power in. Its fun. its simple and you can play it while doing a bunch of other things. Its better than minesweeper and solitaire. 

Worth the price for a uber basic PRIVATEER-like 2D retro trader game that doesn't take itself too seriously. Well for a few bucks to blast pirates or be one yourself.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026942236', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 998, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 913, 'last_played': 1612403347}
review:
Honestly, this is one of the best games I've ever purchased on steam. It's the perfect combination of gameplay, storyline, grinding, and just blows my mind with how simply enjoyable it is.

You're probably looking at about 12-15 hours of gameplay out of this purchase, but it is a very high quality 12-15 hours. 100% worth the purchase. I don't know what you're waiting for. Click the purchase button.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068116100', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2599, 'playtime_forever': 712, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 712, 'last_played': 1582211808}
review: Uzay temasının eşliğinde birçok maceraya girişebileceğiniz bu oyunda; eski tarz oyun içerik parçalarını görebilirsiniz. Bu uzay oyununda adım attığınız maceralarda zorluklarla da karşılaşıp, o zorluklara çözümler üretmeye çalışabilirsiniz. Bütün bunların yanı sıra oyunda karşınıza çıkabilen görevleri de tamamlamaya çalışıp, o görevlerin önünüze neler çıkarabileceğine bir göz atabilirsiniz.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979050956', 'num_games_owned': 638, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 775, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 775, 'last_played': 1581933076}
review: I had to do a speedrun in order to complete the main story, but man I'm pleasently surprised, the game is fun and have a lot of thing to do, quests to complete and surprises to discover, is also fun with a special sense of humour. Even If  already completed the main quest there are still a ton of things to do, stations to visit, jobs to complete and ships to buy, If you're interested in Space open world sims but you don't have enough time or are scared of the size of those behemoths, 3030 is for you. Recomended 100%

author: {'steamid': '76561197971008749', 'num_games_owned': 1085, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 998, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 998, 'last_played': 1581863409}
review: Quick answer buy it!...The long...I can not believe i missed this game when it first came out.  I really love this game.  It has a fantastic pixel art style i love with many individuals from other scifi shows, and the style does have an 80/90's throwback feel that compliments the game.  Now the Sound and Music, i got to hand it to the developers who selected these tracks, as they are superb, i really loved the music and it really compliments the look and feel of the game, as the main character has that cool Indiana Jones look it perfectly fits the Indi in space, and although there is some dialogue that may come across as tongue in cheek or even a bit rude, it perfectly sums up the type of criminals you will be dealing with.  The UI and controls are a little rigid and unfriendly to some, but i actually thought it complimented the games style perfectly.  I had my doubts at first but wow what a game.  This is a gem and really appreciate all the work they put into this game.  It shows in its simple yet addictive play style.  It can be a little bit of a grind at times with the mission types and the main plot does seem to somewhat short, however it could be because i could not stop playing this game.  It reminded me of old games like Master Of Orion 2(Moo2) simple yet deceptively deep.  I wish for more complex plots and twists but really that is only because i want more...much more.  In summing up Buy it!...I was blown away by the look and feeling of love put into this game, it left me wanting more, always a good sign of a game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065877448', 'num_games_owned': 4151, 'num_reviews': 303, 'playtime_forever': 913, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 827, 'last_played': 1582152281}
review:
It's a good top-down space adventure game. The story is engaging and includes unique gameplay elements, but it's pretty short. It only took me about 10 hours to complete, including a couple hours of grinding for a better ship (that got taken away from me by the story anyway, so I had to grind it again). The mid- to endgame goes by crazy fast as there are a couple hefty cash incentives you get for visiting every system and completing the game, catapulting you pretty much entirely over the $2-$3 mil ships if you're not spending it on upgrades, which I think is a shame. It means you spend most of your time with the worst ships or the best ships, so a lot of the ship variety goes to waste.

A huge bugbear I have with the game is the lack of unique scripted missions. There are [b]zero[/b] scripted side quests. Everything is procedural with very little variation outside of the story mode. You'll be doing the same handful of mission types the whole time. Even other smaller space games like Void Destroyer 2 know that just a handful of uniquely scripted sidequests really serve to liven up your universe. This game... doesn't have them for some reason.

The story mode and the 80's atmosphere and odd neo-noir aesthetic are the driving force behind this game, with the 80's-inspired pop soundtrack really serving to set the mood as you do the same things you do in every other space adventure game, just... easier. There's no challenge here. Fortunately, the game's story is written in an entertaining manner and the ending is incredibly cathartic. Like, the ending is really, [i]really[/i] good. But once you beat it, all you've really got left is whatever fun you can make for yourself, and maybe trying to get the most expensive ship in the game. That's it; there's almost no way you'll hit 100 hours with this sort of procedural quest system unless your entertainment standards are abysmally low. But for 10-20 hours depending on what you do, it'll give you a giggle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082331544', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 1238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 564, 'last_played': 1705883658}
review:
This is a fun take on starship based space exploration mixed perfectly with a more personal character centered experience. The universe is fun and fleshed out, the main characters are interesting and enjoyable, dialog options fun.

Nothing to dislike as far as I can tell!  Almost feels old Space Ace, point and click-ee in places.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013328690', 'num_games_owned': 686, 'num_reviews': 261, 'playtime_forever': 1718, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1070, 'last_played': 1580309361}
review:
Freelancer in 2d.
perfect audio-visual-style, one of the best OSTs out there (which you actualy get to listen to unlike Death Stranding's), 
great, tight gameplay. trade, mine, kill/hunt bounties, pirate, race, deliver packes/cargo, make photos, play taxi-driver, explore derilicts in a mini-game, etc. .  
a metric ton of different ships, star-systems, weapons and upgrades.

now this might be subjectual but i realy, realy love the HUD and the UI, they work perfectly, give you all the information you need, but most important: they look the part. in many games you get stellar 3d-grafic, but an UI/HUD straight from good old PS1 days. the whole design fits perfectly and never breaks the immersion.

all this gets rounded up by a sometimes hillarious, often and interesting main-plot and absolutly loveable characters.

beeing it the visual style, the quirky characters, the glorious soundtrack: the game is just fun and upbeat. 

haven't bought this pearl yet? what's wrong with you?

author: {'steamid': '76561198062926125', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 392, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 223, 'last_played': 1580631711}

author: {'steamid': '76561198046000711', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1029, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 930, 'last_played': 1585538678}

author: {'steamid': '76561198009563074', 'num_games_owned': 389, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1552, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 985, 'last_played': 1578759709}
review:
This is a neat game although I like the idea of the game better than the game itself. Being av fan of Elite since the days of C64 and Amiga I have a special affinity for open world space games. The storytellning reminds me alot of Monkey Island which is not a bad thing. Some parts of the game are kind of weak but the sum of all parts are a good game.

There clearly are some technical issues, but my estimate is that if you have patience and a general knowhow of computers you will be able to get it running the way you like. I had to crawl around the forums for a bit to get the game playing in full screen without stuttering and also get my joypad working. The impression I got is that caring devs and a strong community probably has solved most issues you will face in one way or another.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020448520', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 793, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 793, 'last_played': 1578440687}

author: {'steamid': '76561198041983024', 'num_games_owned': 487, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 886, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 878, 'last_played': 1590580213}
review: Solid game feel and core gameplay loop. Story is okay, but the actual gameplay and variety makes up for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042668936', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 238, 'last_played': 1595292955}
review: Hidden Gem of the year!

author: {'steamid': '76561197960420790', 'num_games_owned': 1549, 'num_reviews': 399, 'playtime_forever': 454, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 454, 'last_played': 1577745793}
review:
Deathwar 3030 is an interesting Escape-velocity clone that adds a thin Adventure-game-esque dialogue layer on top of the traditional Elite-em-up genre, and it's a game that's up to its eye-balls in janky, inconsistent implementation. Everything about this game screams "it's a labour of love by an amateur developers that are bravely developing way outside of their comfort zones", and I'm not sure it's really worth playing.


The biggest, jankiest problem with the game is that it's simply a mass of cobbled together systems/things with no overarching UX or game design. This inconsistency is annoying as a) it increases the friction involved when first learning the game and, once learnt, when playing it; b) it seems like this kind of thing is unnoticed by the developers or that they simply don't care/have time, which means players will feel the game isn't the "best" it could be. 

Some examples of tedious inconsistency:

* Information is presented in a completely inconsistent way. Message appear all over the screen - top left, top right, middle, bottom, in menus etc. There's no one, single place you need to look to see important information, you need to look everywhere. 

* When the spaceship controls are set to "mouse + keyboard", you get a very useful dotted line showing where the front of the ship is and where it intersects the outer edge of the HUD. This is useful for navigating when warping between stars... but it's not needed when you have a mouse cursor. Yet the line is not present when set to keyboard-only, which is when it would be genuinely useful!

* On a similar theme, when in adventure game mode, when exploring a derelict ship, and when using "keyboard only ship controls", space bar is "fire". Yet when using "keyboard + mouse" ship controls space is now suddenly used to deactivate the controls.... why? Why not keep it consistent with everything else and keep it as fire, and make some other random button "deactivate controls"?? 

* Infact, keys aren't even remappable, meaning I can't change this madness myself.

* The mission scripting is all over the place. Some things are "missions" that you can see in the mission list, and others are "contacts". Both end up with you going places, talking to people, and getting paid. But the contacts thing was presumably chosen for some of the missions to let you workaround their own weird saving system that doesn't let you save when you have a "mission", but is fine when you have a contract??? Also some of the "contact" mission sequences (e.g. the gold ship) just randomly disappear without explaining themselves.

* The graphics implementation is a very "brave choice", though I often feel like it wasn't much of a choice as more of a "best we can do", as the developers thought that scaling, rotating, and filtering hand-drawn pixel art was a good idea. (It's not! Why ruin the nice art?)


But it's not all doom and gloom, 

e.g. 
* the look and theme of the game is very interesting
* the music and the way it changes is a nice touch (though varies in quality!)


Still, in terms of gameplay it suffers from a clear lack of polish in terms of the experience a player goes through.
e.g. The game is clearly intended to be played as a "story", but yet it also presents it self as an "open world, do anything!" kind of game, even going so far as to use those terms. But "doing anything" just means you get way ahead of the intended power-curve and the story missions are then rather trivial and boring to play through. I'm aware that even AAA "open world" titles suffer this problem, and it's not an easy one to solve, but the game makes no attempt to solve it.

Infact I'm surprised the game even wants you to do it's open-world stuff, 
as the open world gameplay is quite boring. Trading is tedious, as it requires the player to manually take note of a system's good's prices (yawn) and you can't see a system's prices until you get there (double-yawn). To top it all off: it doesn't make enough money! You can make most of the money from pick-up-and-deliver missions and bounty hunting, which are much more interesting. Some also comes from "salvage" missions which are weird little mini-games were you float through an empty ship picking up stuff, but that's also tedious and jankily implemented.


So the janktactular nature of the game means that even though it's quite enjoyable to play, and kinda satisfies the Escape-velocity itch, I could only actually will myself to play if I  "got past" the inconsistency issues and directionless "game design".  Which means it just leaves me wanting to play Escape Velocity: Nova or some other better-implemented game in this style.
developer_response:
Hi Pod,

thanks for your write-up. This game has been a passion project for us, developed over the course of well over 10 years. We worked on it besides our main jobs, and so only had limited time and resources to spend, which might help explain some of your complaints.

We agree that saving the game anytime, rebindable key controls and nicer graphics would be pretty great, but we had to decide between that and making the missions and story more fun, and ended up going with the latter.

In the end, we just wanted to make the most enjoyable game for people to play, and tried to add as much stuff that made the experience as fun as possible, but that also meant having to cut some features unfortunately. 

In any case, we hope the game was still somewhat enjoyable to you. Thanks for the feedback, and thanks for playing the game!

- Max, Matt and Mike

author: {'steamid': '76561197999597403', 'num_games_owned': 182, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 20, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1577188367}
review: Returned for refund.  The visual quality was way better on the videos selling the product than my game play experience.  I have a top of the line machine so there is no excuse.  The controls didn't work as on screen instructions indicated.  I had issues with movement and actions.  For me this is unplayable.  Also too much reading to be fun.
developer_response:
Hi Bodyparts,

thanks for the feedback. 

Could you perhaps explain what you mean with the visual quality being better on the videos? The trailers show only in-game material, so we don't really understand what you mean.

And could you perhaps let us know which controls weren't working and you had issues with? We worked on making the controls and tutorial as streamlined as possible, and this is not a complaint we usually get.

Best,
Max and the 3030 Team

author: {'steamid': '76561198011970479', 'num_games_owned': 578, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 2204, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 619, 'last_played': 1577491780}

author: {'steamid': '76561197982615575', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 176, 'playtime_forever': 164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 164, 'last_played': 1572463970}
review:
I kind of liked this game, but can't really recommend it.

 It's a little Escape Velocity type of game with very charming presentation.

As far as the gameplay, the ship control feels pretty good and I like zip zooming around blasting things to some extent, but it's also got some issues.  First, no lateral thrust is kind of disappointing, but not a huge problem.  Second, the way ship weapons are handled is kind of awful.  Your ship has a front weapon mount, and maybe a turret weapon mount, but you can't fire them separately (???) which is awful.  Also, you're supposed to be able to left click to fire your turret/weapon, but it doesn't work, so you're stuck holding down spacebar to fire.

The UI is minimal to the point of barely being functional.  The radar appears as a faded out overlay in the center of the screen, which sucks.  The Map is very bare bones and so is the navigation UI, leading to situations where it just feels like a janky pain in the ass to travel to places. 

But I did enjoy the story vignettes (you are running from space mafia hitmen), the mission system works well, and blasting enemy ships can be fun if you stick to only turret or only mounted weapons.  It's OK.  I think if you really want to play an EV style game and you're already tired of stuff like Drox Operative, you should play this.  If not, I wouldn't bother.  Sale purchase, maybe.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072932385', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 695, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 223, 'last_played': 1577340390}
review: 3030 is a great space sandbox adventure game. The 1980s futurism is charming. It takes the best parts of other games in the genre, such as Dangerous Elite or EVE, and presents them in a less tedious way. Overall fun little gem.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062971107', 'num_games_owned': 833, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 1276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 732, 'last_played': 1598819465}
review:
This is like 2D Elite Dangerous, kind of. Dialogue is quirky, and the soundtrack is on point. 
Tons of ships to buy, tons of weapons and upgrades, definitely recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039746327', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 903, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 903, 'last_played': 1553494884}
review:
A very fun little Space Odyssey with a quirky sense of humour and a lot of cool ships and upgrades to be found throughout your playthrough.

I found the modding community to be very small, so replayability perhaps isn't great. And I found the controller support non-functional with my genuine xbox controller, something the devs seem aware of but are either unable or unwilling to fix.

But I enjoyed the game nonetheless, and if anyone ever does mod up another mission campaign for it I'll definitely jump back in. As is, the official content is probably good for 10-15 hours - not to be sniffed at, but something you might want to pick up on a sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986715648', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 802, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 802, 'last_played': 1575840721}
review:
It's an ok game. I recommend it if it is on sale. 

It has a nice retro vibe to it. You basically do various missions, salvage, mine or fight to work your way up to get better ships. The whole goal seems to be to get the next up ship. I believe M8 or M9 is the best and I have made it to M5 so far. The missions, which I do the most out of all the options to make money, are either photo missions, assassin missions, taxi missions, tow cargo missions or package missions. It never varies outside that. In a way, you can look at money like experience since you need more money to get the next up ship. The game is a grind, which is why I have not finished it yet. Doing quests for anywhere between $4000 a pop up to the rare $80,000 missions makes ships in the millions look like a daunting task.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005755324', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 387, 'last_played': 1576334591}
review: A cool, charismatic and immersive Sci-fi game. However, the save system is not good at all; you can only save if you have no current missions, and the autosaves are extremely far in-between. The result is that it's easy to loose several hours worth of progress early on, until you have trained yourself to stop picking up missions all the time. The problem is: this is a game where you constantly need to do missions, you fully depend on collecting them en masse, in order to upgrade and earn money..The whole game is built around the player grinding out missions. To plan your missions around save points in this way is bad design for this kind of gameplay. For Dark Souls-types? maybe, for mission-grinding? nope. Once you learn to limit your mission grinding though, you can settle into a gameworld that's quirky, humorous, highly detailed, extravagant, large in scope, and fun to play in. Apart from the above issue, it's a really well-made game, you can tell it was made with tonnes of passion, dedication and skill. It's hard not to be impressed. It's not that often you come across Indie games with this kind of scope and depth.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032737008', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 781, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 413, 'last_played': 1650011731}

review:
Gameplay is 9/10
Story is 2/10
Most music is copyrighted but still 9/10 for music

Only problem is that after you complete the story there is nothing for you to do other than do more jobs, trade, fight and buy ships. All of those things you would have already been doing throughout the story and don't change at all after the story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032239354', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 167, 'playtime_forever': 372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 372, 'last_played': 1575305748}
review: I honestly would love to recommend this game, as the whole concept of combining space sim and adventure game is brilliant! However, the space combat itself is very clunky and is in larger role than I hoped for, thus making the game almost unplayable for me after leaving the first sector.
developer_response:
Hi Vesectomboy,

thanks for the feedback!

You can actually choose how much or how little space combat you want to have in your game. If you avoid certain mission types and events like MONEYBALL, you shouldn't have very much combat at all.

Another good way of making this more enjoyable is upgrading your ship with a turret and missiles. These are much easier to fight with, and will hopefully make combat a lot more fun for you.

You can also go to the game options and set the "Gang activity" setting to the lowest setting, so you don't get the occasional hit squads attacking you later in the story.

I hope some of this helps!

Best,
Max and the 3030 Team

author: {'steamid': '76561197970891056', 'num_games_owned': 643, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 580, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 580, 'last_played': 1573311224}
review: This game is a little bit like if an old Lucasarts adventure and Escape Velocity had a child. The oldschool feel is great for an old fart like me. Nostalgia aside, the game definitely manages to stand on its own with the mix between top-down freeform space game and point and click adventure game with fine art and music. The humor and story is enjoyable and the same goes for the music. The only part of the game that felt "meh" to me was the salvage element when you board derelicts. Those sequences work, but doesn't add much to the experience. All in all it's a great game though, and you can really tell that a lot of love went into its development.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964070943', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 135, 'last_played': 1573382287}
review:
Great concept but horribly executed.

Everything in this game feels like it's harder than it should be when it comes to the controls. I had no idea what I was doing or where I was going when I was in the ship/shuttle. It all seems very confusing which is why I had to stop playing...

Maybe there is a great game in there somewhere but I wasn't willing to stick around for it. I just think the combination of all the techniques from different genres was not executed right. It feels like all the elements are fighting each other rather than working in harmony. 

Not very good IMO...

author: {'steamid': '76561198329471730', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2812, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2146, 'last_played': 1576453525}
review:
Have you ever wanted to be a space scoundrel like Han Solo, but dressed like Indiana Jones? Do you love the the aesthetics of Blade Runner, Firefly, Fifth Element, Cowboy Bebop, Outlaw Star and Star Wars? 
Then 3030 Deathwar Redux is for you.
Every screen looks like Adam Savage crafted it and aged it. The space ports are filled with unique characters.
There are some great mods too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060692740', 'num_games_owned': 257, 'num_reviews': 201, 'playtime_forever': 1561, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1233, 'last_played': 1598845640}
review:
This game is fun if you like cool vibes and quirky dialogue. You are a top-down-when-flying-side-scrolling-point-and-click-when-walking space vagrant slash rogue hero who gets conscripted into doing a cross-galaxy super secret agent quest, alongside doing other missions to earn money, upgrade to bigger, awesomer ships, and better weapons. Did I mention the VIBE???

ACHIEVEMENT EDIT 8/30/2020: OK I ADMIT IT, I CONFESS, I cheated to get the 10 and 100 million credits acheivements. So there. To be clear, I used the in game console to change the value of a certain quest to pay out an extremely high amount. If you're using external programs to cheat steam achievements, that's a WEIRDCHAMP from me

author: {'steamid': '76561197990258343', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1070, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1070, 'last_played': 1571246163}
review:
Yeah!!!!!! Well, I LOVE open world space games... and this one is no exception! Well, as I'm not a gamer who plays 5+hours per day, and can't grind like hell as others do, this game had for me the right balance, if not a bit too easy, said. 17 hours on, game finished. Was it fun? Yes... was it rewardfull? Yes.... to be honest the game mechanics could have been a bit more complicated or dig deeper some technological aquisition to the ship, but... I had great time flying around, killing bugs on the mission boards, hunting pirates, upgrade ship, buying new ships etc...
It was the 8€ (promotion of 50% that day I bought it) worth it!
Hope there'll be a "2" sometimes... would buy it too!

author: {'steamid': '76561198000638263', 'num_games_owned': 731, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 949, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 949, 'last_played': 1571422828}

review:

This game seems cool, the concept is great, I DO really want to play it. But I think the pure indie-low-budget-ness has stopped me sticking with it so far... It's one of those games... I bought it, didn't get into it, but didn't refund because I liked it enough to keep it for laterz.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064646555', 'num_games_owned': 201, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 688, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 206, 'last_played': 1641032710}
review:
当不了星际牛仔我当星际快递员还不行么？---一名因燃料没带够迷失在宇宙某星系的中年男子留下的遗言

没有汉化这个文字量差点就把我劝退了，不过当我驾驶飞船在茫茫星海中，bgm响起来的那一瞬间，真的鸡皮疙瘩掉了一地。

“姑娘你去哪个星球，我顺路捎你一段儿，给个油钱就行。”

author: {'steamid': '76561197995067163', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 930, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 930, 'last_played': 1547926809}
review:
A fun space adventure in the same vein as Endless Sky or Escape Velocity. If you've never played either of those: it's a very light shoot-em up with trade routes.

The thing that sets this game apart from the others in its genre is the story. There's actually a reason to go do things in this sector of space, and sometimes you'll do those things purposefully, and other times you'll happen to stumble in the right direction to set off the plot. The main protagonist is someone you can root for, and the villain is just a little (but not much) more than just plain evil.

It's short and sweet - a playthrough will take you about 15 hours - but there's no reason to stop playing just because the story's over. There's trading to do between the star systems, and you could always set a goal for yourself to save up enough cash to get yourself a really nice ship.

If you're still not sure, you can watch [url=https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLXZVJl1bW2P3McpepxQ-IgPw0BwWbv9j]my playthrough[/url], but be warned: spoilers ahoy!

author: {'steamid': '76561198185923709', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 737, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 737, 'last_played': 1569890106}
review: I would love to recommend this game, but  in its current state I can't.  The inability to save your game while you have an active mission is infuriating.  The entire game is centred around completing missions to upgrade your ship.  You will almost always have active missions.  The amount of progress I've lost (on multiple occasions) because I was either unexpectedly attacked and killed or because I had to go do something in real life but wasn't allowed to save my game is ridiculous.  Alas, I had to uninstall the game without completing it.  Too bad...it really has a lot going for it and the gameplay itself is excellent and somewhat addictive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029821356', 'num_games_owned': 192, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1300, 'last_played': 1555513372}

author: {'steamid': '76561197994868694', 'num_games_owned': 412, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 67, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1554522662}

author: {'steamid': '76561197971528728', 'num_games_owned': 389, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1443, 'last_played': 1659916870}
review: This game is amazing. I was looking for something similar to freelancer, or solar winds... There's a lot to do in this.  It's genuinely funny. The story isn't super long, but the size of the map is impressive and you could just get lost in sidequests, which are pretty much infinite. I highly recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983670473', 'num_games_owned': 361, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1569105325}
review:
Хмммммммммммм... очень странная игра .....

Отличная музыка, но нет звуковых эффектов практически вообще. Нет разговоров, выстрелов на станции, работы с терминалами и т.д.. То есть ок - в космосе ничего не слышно (допустим, даже в аркаде), но - в баре, на станции, с кучей неписей!? Нет "атмосферы", вообще. То есть, нет даже попытки.

Много интересных игровых механик: разные корабли, торговля, апгрейды, различные трудности путешествий к другим звёздам. Юмор, закос под 80-ые.

По моему, конечно, глубоко субъективному мнению - игра по-настоящему всрата. Просто в недумении, как можно было не сделать примитивных звуков лифта, шагов, бла-бла аля sims...

Поэтому, настоятельно рекомендую морально подготовиться перед тратой кровных.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017901429', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 876, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 716, 'last_played': 1570328730}

author: {'steamid': '76561198001476747', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4004, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2927, 'last_played': 1706810234}
review: I found this game to be a lot of fun. It has the jobs, the pirates, the bounty hunting, and all that jazz, similar to Rebel Galaxy. The graphics however, are much simpler. That doesn't deter me in the least. What surprised me was how funny this game is. There is some really funny stuff. Some of the lines are subtle and then hilarious when you get them. Give this one a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198160103045', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1245, 'last_played': 1522189018}
review: This feels like it's half finished. There's lots of nice flavor text, but the gameplay is bunk. Exploring derelicts is is shallow, safe, and repetitive. Trading is just an unrewarding way to learn to hate the really good soundtrack, and taxi jobs are same plus time limit. This could all be overlooked if the combat was in any way the slightest bit ok. Turns out to be the worst part of the game. Combat is tedious strafing with minimal variety. You're left with no other tactical options since the view only lets you see within punching distance. I waited a while before reviewing to see if the modding community would make this into something cool, but the workshop is unenthusiastic. If you see this going for five dollars, you'll get your money's worth.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058163516', 'num_games_owned': 138, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 1097, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1097, 'last_played': 1568404049}

author: {'steamid': '76561197999258025', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 193, 'last_played': 1597095935}
review: It's unfortunate, I've tried multiple times to play this game.  It looks great, but the lack of key-remapping makes it very difficult to play as I'm left-handed and use a left-handed mouse.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000607253', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2377, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2376, 'last_played': 1568069295}
review: Was a fun charming game. Reminiscent of escape velocity for old fans of that classic mac shareware game, but with it's own unique take and spin on the mechanics. Not for everyone but if you enjoy retro light privateer/elite style games from 2d overhead view where you can fight/trade/explore in open world fashion but there is an overarching plot to follow with text dialogue and storyline and animated sequences. Also does not take it's self too seriously. Can take a minute to acclimate to the overlays/interface, and some initial grinding involved. IMO this is largely integral to the genre, like privateer and EV, start small shuttle and build up. This does not feel excessive nor does it feel like the ends of the game, just the means to get there. Good quick guide on steam to glance at to get started and avoid frustration.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970661562', 'num_games_owned': 446, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 801, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 793, 'last_played': 1610521262}
review:
3030 Deathwar Redux - A  Space Odyssey, known from here on in as Deathwar, is a game of many parts. Some of these parts are good, like the jam in a sponge cake. Some of these parts are bad, like the rest of a sponge cake. Let's run through what makes Deathwar tick (and I'll ditch the cake analogy - for now).

First up, flying around in space. Here you'll pilot a 2D ship through 2D space, beautifully rendered in 24 caret sci-fi themed pixel art. There's combat, junk busting, cargo collecting, exploring, missions, and possibly a few other things I've forgotten. It works well, runs smoothly and has a few quirks and perks along the way to keep things fresh (pilots randomly offering to help, or to sell you illicit goods).

Then there's the on-station portion of the game. When you need to stop off and stretch your legs, you dock with a space station and get around in a side scrolling, adventure style UI. Pretty much all stations look and play the same (with art changes on the bar area and different styles of background, but fundamentally it's the same makeup every time). You can go to the bar and talk to the patrons; interesting for the first few dozen times but after that you'll start ignoring all but those required to fulfill your current mission. There's also a mission computer and a market/ship/parts computer. Pretty run of the mill, you take various kinds of missions to make money and sometimes advance the story. Ships get bigger, faster, better, have more storage etc, depending on how you want to play. You can play the market and be a trader, but I found the mission route was far more lucrative and only went to the market for fuel and to sell the crap I found on salvage missions (more in a second). Very occasionally you have to fight someone with your pistol while on the station. The shooting part worked about as well as pasting head-shots of your new girlfriend over the face of your old girlfriend on the pics you have hanging over your fireplace. Actually I'm not sure that analogy works, but I spent five minutes dreaming it up so it stays. Stations play a valuable role in the theme and feel of the game, while the shooting part felt shoehorned in, slapped over the top for the hell of it. It was just one more thing they tried to jam into an already crowded game - one thing too far. I mean, now I read that statement and compare it with my girlfriend analogy, it's painfully clear how crap that analogy is. Moving on.

Salvage. When encountering a hulk you have the option of conducting a salvage run. This was pretty cool the first 10 times, zipping about in your space suit, zapping aliens, collecting cool stuff and looting the dead meat popsicles. After that magical 10th time it kind of waned in entertainment value, which is a shame. You weren't forced to salvage but it could be a lucrative income stream. I'm not sure what the developer could do anything to improve things without an overhaul; the mould was cast and each salvage mission played out like like the previous ones. Float, dodge, shoot, grab, escape. Never once did I feel particularly threatened.

Now take these parts, smoosh them into a single game, and what do you have? Is it coherent? Like the proverbial sponge cake, you have some good parts (the jam center), some okay bits you can tolerate (the cake), and some parts you sort of ignore or flick off onto your plate (cream, half priced fruit the baker added in a failed and misguided attempt to jazz things up). I loved the first ten hours of Deathwar. Zipping here and there, zapping this and that, getting into the game loop of making money, exploring a bit more, getting a new ship, upgrading that ship, taking on new missions. Repeat. The story was ok. I could ignore the dull bits and it just sort of progressed on its own time-frame. Then, once more akin to the majestic sponge cake, it all stopped being fun and became a chore. The words "rinse, repeat" spring to mind.

If Deathwar was the only game I owned, I may have persisted. I mean, it's not bad - in fact, it's quite a good game - I just don't love this sort of game enough to persist and push through. Like every gamer these days, my collection is frighteningly large and half of them remain unplayed, or with a play time still shy of the single digit hour mark. Therefore, I dropped it. Right or wrong, fair or not, I felt I'd played though all the cool content, seen what there was to see, and future content was all going to be variations on the same themes. However, I can definitely see that if you do like this sort of game, or love the art style, then that'll be enough for you to plow on and see the end credits.

With all of that said and all of the caveats and the hand wringing and the fact I dropped it after 13 hours, it is with only a tiny amount of hesitation that I recommend 3030 Deathwar. It was a game I loved, then played casually, then dropped like an old sponge cake I just found at the back of the fridge in an orange Tupperware container.

VERDICT: Layered like a sponge cake, no wait...damn it I should have used layer cake as an analogy. Anyway, like a dessert option with more than one component, Deathwar is greater than the sum of its parts and can be enjoyed as one big, messy whole. Definitely worth playing on the cheap, or worth playing anytime if you love this kind of game (Space Pirates and Zombies comes to mind as something similar).

Final Word: It's a decent game with lots of parts. RECOMMENDED

(shit, I forgot to say the music was cool. Hey, the music is cool!)

More reviews at Belligerent Older Gamers - https://belligerentoldergamers.blogspot.com/

author: {'steamid': '76561198353155991', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 925, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 728, 'last_played': 1680640809}
review: This game is beautiful in many ways. The graphics are amazing and run very well at high resolution even with low-quality graphics cards. The music is incredibly well suited for the game, and is a joy to listen to. If you ever wanted just a normal, fun game to play without bugs and hassles with setting things up and adjusting your graphics setting and figuring out that you can't even play the game at full resolution and just plain work? Well here you go. Everything is sweet and simple. Enjoy!

author: {'steamid': '76561198066263103', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 1170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1567429858}
review:
SO GOOD.

Lots of recommendations from people I trust.  Had it on my wishlist a long time, and finally picked it up.

I think I was hesitant because of the cheesy title, but this game has it all:

- EV-like game loop:  Truck, Taxi, Trade, Mercenary, Pirate
- Lucasarts SCUMM-VM like adventure: Point-and-click adventure game on stations, funny dialogue, cutscenes, nice story.
- Well paced upgrade paths, technology trickled out such that you get to experience a bunch of it and not just plot optimal paths through the tech tree
- lots of options.  different ship choices for different playstyles
- combat not too hard
- Free-roaming sandbox game world that can be explored while doing the story

Loving every bit of it so far.

author: {'steamid': '76561198314822616', 'num_games_owned': 156, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 705, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 149, 'last_played': 1661316833}

author: {'steamid': '76561198035129071', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 169, 'last_played': 1567257220}

author: {'steamid': '76561198047914588', 'num_games_owned': 583, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 573, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 573, 'last_played': 1566464075}
review:
On a surface level, 3030 Deathwar should be a good time. The main gameplay loop is solid, you bounce from system to system doing various missions and upgrading your ship. The top down space combat, while simplistic, is brisk and chaotic, and is the part of the game I enjoyed most. Unfortunately, the missions themselves are a major letdown and a tedious slog.

Side missions, which is what you'll be spending most of your time on, are incredibly tedious. Most consist of traveling from point A to point B or from point A to point B to point C. Nothing interesting happens along the way, no pirates to contend with, no random events, no challenge aside from watching your fuel gauge. The only obstacle are nebulas, which only serve to slow you down and annoy me to no end. Bounty hunting is fun at first, but gets old quick thanks to how the behavior of pirates never change, they always use the same tactics and their ships have little variation. Mining consists of parking your ship next to asteroids and pressing a button, slightly more engaging than delivery errands but that's not saying much. Derelicts earn you little money and become just as repetitive as everything else.

For the most part, the story missions are just reskinned side missions. The adventure bits where you walk around on the surface of a planet or shoot killer robots with a dinky pistol were enjoyable, but these happen so infrequently that they can't make up for the lack of variation in the main story missions. The only interesting story mission apart from these adventure segments was near the end of the game when I had to take on a small fleet in order to destroy a larger ship. I really wished the developers focused more on the adventure bits and made more of them. The story itself is rather forgettable. A few lines did give me a chuckle and I do enjoy the main character's interactions with others. Otherwise, the story is a rather generic doomsday plot that loses steam halfway through the game.

A big issue is the fact that the game never progresses in any substantial way. In the 9 hours I played, the pay rate for the average mission never rose beyond $30,000 while ship costs rose higher and higher. The missions were the exact same hour 1 as they were in hour 9, only that you would have to travel farther and with a time limit. Once you did each type of mission, you pretty much did them all. The exception to this were bounties, which would add enemies protecting the bounty if the reward is higher. Still, this capped out at around 3-4 additional enemies and sometimes those enemies wouldn't spawn, leading to an easy fight that was over in a few seconds. The ships don't really change much either aside from basic stats. Each ship has a single front weapon and/or a turret with some missiles, that's it. There is an upgrade that doubles your front weapon output, but it still doesn't change much and I never saw an enemy with this upgrade. Each fight plays out the exact same way with no variation, run circles around the enemy and occasionally activate ECM to destroy missiles. There are no special weapons like a gravity bomb or a harpoon to play around with, all weapons either shoot a generic energy projectile or a laser beam.

There is nothing particularly frustrating or horrible about 3030 Deathwar, but there's nothing really great about it either. It's a few good moments buried under a slew of forgettable filler. Even though the developers said that it took them 10 years to make this, it certainly doesn't feel like it needed to take this long.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084674911', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 1021, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 524, 'last_played': 1574111780}
review:
Oddly addictive retro 90s style ega pixel graphics game with really great music!! Im not a big fan of the genre, but the selections of music is really good, it fits and I didnt want to reach for my volume once.  It took me a little bit to get the hang of it, but it is super fun and a great way to spend a few hours with nothing else to do.  SHHHHH, that's what I tell my wife anyway!  In reality, its fun as hell and hard to put down with a yard full of grass to be cut, ah heck it isnt going anywhere! Galaxy exploration is where its at! You get to take missions, hunt down pirates and use a tractor beam to retrieve the loot and bodies, plunder derilect ships for treasure and use a tractor beam to retrieve the bodies! Go rogue and play crash em up derby to knock loot lose from other ships and use the tractor beam to retrieve the loot.  Did I mention you need a tractor beam!?  You can build money pretty fast with a couple of missions as well as shooting loot around the stations.  Its pretty fast and easy to upgrade, and upgrade you must do!  But its fun and it isnt a boring grind for hours doing it.  No, those hours are spent testing your lastest missiles and cannons to bring home more loot! Yeah, it's plenty of fun! That is until the pirate I took out dropped a freaking plasma bomb as his ship blew up, I, like a noooooob  ran right into it and boom!! Good thing the game auto saves every time you dock at a station! There is also a manual save so you can outfit your ship like you want it then save it and refuel before you ride out again into the stary night in search of that pirate that killed you with that freaking plasma bomb! 

highly recommended if you like retro games!

author: {'steamid': '76561198008630526', 'num_games_owned': 1740, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 284, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1547603909}
review:
I might not have many hours on Steam, but I have easily dozens of hours with this game on the go.
If you are looking for a fun space sandbox, that's not too complicated, Deathwar is a great buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198347037868', 'num_games_owned': 88, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 6979, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4618, 'last_played': 1703546717}
review: hilarious characters, great setting, really fun gameplay, but the music and story are fantastic. the whole game is chocked full of retro references and humor that never ends. I've played this game way too much! It has the typical job console for taxi, delivery, pirate bounty etc but there are also side missions to get with little bits of story, just have to talk to the people on the stations. if typical taxi/delivery stuff bores you, just stick to bounty missions, and you can always hunt pirates without having to go to the job console. some systems they show up often enough to make great money.optional mining and salvage missions are real time and a lot of fun. If youre into the retro space shooters, this is game has some of the best atmosphere, story and gameplay available

author: {'steamid': '76561197995279722', 'num_games_owned': 553, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 814, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 814, 'last_played': 1565933677}
review:
Its a decent 2d space-trucker / privateer game.  Similar games in the genre: Escape Velocity, Endless Sky, Star Control, Rebel Galaxy.  If you like the gameplay loop of making money and upgrading ships through the usual means (trading/mining/exploring/bounty-hunting/pirating)... chances are you'll enjoy this one.  Its a genre that there needs to be a lot more of, in my opinion.  And this is a relatively recommendable entry.  A bit short, though.  And no side-quests.  You're going to be either mainlining the story or doing repeatable missions with a little optional exploration sprinkled in.


Pros:
+ Lots of ships to choose from.  Mostly boils down to fighters or traders, but other options are there.
+ Lots of ship system upgrades.  The majority of these are straightforward (e.g. shield recharge rate), but there are a few creative ideas that give your vehicle a more personal and 'realistic' feel.  Many of which add new UI elements to your screen.
+ Ship flight feels good
+ Progression to better ships and upgrades feels natural and goes at a good pace for the most part.
+ Lots of visual detail in and around stations gives a pretty unique feel to the game.
+ Very friendly and helpful devs.  Very small team... true indies.

= A couple interesting attempts at genre-blending... Namely: the on-station adventure game element... and the "twin-stick shooter lite" scavenging mini-game.  Disappointingly, neither of these have much depth to them.  Dialogue choice has no consequences at all from what I could tell.  There is no challenge or risk/reward system to the adventure or scavenging aspects.  For example: perhaps they could have added some in-station adventures as sidequests with some light puzzles that would unlock some sort of unique ship, weapon, or upgrade.  Perhaps the ship-scavenging could have been made shorter, or expanded upon.  Still, these little detours from space trucking weren't terrible, and they serve as a short break from the norm.
= Station computer missions are the usual.  A decent variety of them, but they are all pretty basic.  None of them lead to anything more interesting.  Deliver package here.  Kill pirate outside.  Take picture and bring it back.

- No customizable controls.
- Lack of modern fullscreen/resolution options.  Beware bugs going past 1080p.
- VERY little content outside of the main story line.  There are a few secrets here and there, but nothing substantial.
- Manual mining and trading are perhaps the slowest and least profitable activities by far.  At least until you get a very large cargo hold.  But by that time you will have seen all of the game's content.
- If you're new to this genre of game (and even if you aren't), the UI is a bit of a mess.  The map system in particular is disjointed.  Even with practice, it seems the map system could have been better designed.  If you're going from one system to the next, you have to sort-of juggle your map controls a bunch to see where you're going.
- Once you leave the tutorial sector, all the content feels VERY cut-and-paste.  Nothing new to discover.  Especially stations.  Not much point in talking to people.
- Very small selection of weapons.  Weapon customization on ships is also extremely bare-bones.  There are, at most, only two slots for weapons on ALL ships; A single forward mount and a single turret mount.  Some ships have only one type.  If you install one in both slots, their fire rate and damage is halved.
- No true ship customization.  Every ship can have the exact same systems installed on them as any other.
- Weapon sounds are awful.  Not going to pull any punches here.


It brings a few neat ideas to the genre, but those ideas aren't really taken to any meaningful lengths.  It's also missing so many simple things that could have made the core combat and gameplay much more satisfying.  Salvaging abandoned pirate ships and taking their ships/weapons, for example.  Or adding a simple hardpoint customization to ships.  Adding more weapon types?

It does the basics so well though, which is why I'm still recommending it.  Its most of what you're looking for in this genre of game, and nothing in 3030 DeathWar Redux is offensively bad.

tl:dr If you know and enjoy this genre, you'll like 3030 Deathwar.  Maybe buy it on sale though if you're on the fence.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053197664', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 490, 'last_played': 1565873391}

author: {'steamid': '76561197971850305', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1563, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1563, 'last_played': 1565662634}
review:
I wanted to balance out the crazy amount of positive reviews with something a little more balanced, albeit frustrated. This game is at best, okay. There are some really decent game play pieces here that just largely go under utilized, or so poorly balanced even though fun, feel like a total waste of time.

There is a huge amount of repetition right from the start, typical of these space merc games admittedly, but this is worse than most simply because of the lack of any variety.  There's only so many times you can read the same quest text about someone's wife recently dying so they can't pay you more before it starts to feel ridiculous.  I have no idea if this is some inside joke or just a genuinely bad random mission generator text.  The reason I mention in joke possibilities is because the game is full of them of which I have absolutely no knowledge of.  

So, all of the random missions are basically the same, and they don't in the slightest pay for the annoyance of doing them.  Destroying debris outside of space stations is supposed to award 250 credits but usually awards just shy of 1k.  Also you can get decent paying missions to complete just to clear junk.  But it makes it clear pretty fast that whats happening is that junk is stacked up oddly, so you shoot 1 junk, get credits and quest credit for 3-4.  You want the best ship in the game, get the fastest cheapest ship and go blow up junk for 2 hours, congratulations, you broke the game.  

So, there is a story which is nice, but its just random jobs, often of obnoxious fedexing things back and forth.  A couple times random mini games are introduced and never seen again, which seems a shame because at least that was variety for 20 seconds.  My favorite part of the story was when I'd gotten myself a nice big beefy ship and the story quest forced me into one of three chosen ones of only modest quality, forcing me to go fly somewhere else, to repurchase the ship i had just bought at a loss.  The story doesn't advance nearly fast enough to keep up with the simple progression of doing a few debris clearing sweeps. The pay ends up feeling insulting, the tasks boring, and then sometimes just massively annoyingly inconvenient for no reason except, if I was feeling really generous, humor.  

Combat is, okay.  There are a lot of upgrades to your ship, except all the guns are basically the same, missiles are expensive and you can't upgrade the durability of your ship at all.  The first ship you get has the same shields as the last ship you'll get. So fighting more than 2 or 3 ship is basically gonna be a big risk of getting wrecked.  The one beam weapon in the game felt so unbelievably strong next to any other gun in the game I basically never changed it.  The range doesn't matter because enemies have the inexplicable ability to teleport right next to you anytime they seem to want.   

Salvaging is fun at first, but falls off so hard in its time to reward ratio that its kind of a waste. Mining on the other hand is painful at first, then becomes by far the easiest way to make cash, aside from the broken debris clearing anyway.

Now that's all the stuff that's okay.  The bad stuff largely concern the navigation mechanics.  An absolutely indecipherable radar system, and multiple awkward key presses for system and "galaxy" maps are very frustrating.  Fuel is a huge pain, that becomes just a non issue as soon as you get a fuel scoop. You can barely upgrade your fuel efficiency so it exists merely as a gate keeping time sink. The nebula exists as an obstacle only as a means of extreme inconvenience.  It holds no navigational, strategic or anything of value, it is a stupid time sink for no reason.  If exploring it provided any sense of value or reward, I wouldn't mind.  

Trying to track loose floating cargo is impossible.  

Dropping way points, called buoys, is a one and done.  So find a wormhole, yay, fast travel.  Except you can't mark it in anyway except with a buoy you can only carry one of at a time, and that you can't rename as far as I could tell. So if you want to mark both ends, you'll need to dock, fly back to the unmarked wormhole and drop another buoy with some generic system name.  Also, buoys are basically invisible on the system map.

Get it on a steep sale, give it a try.  I finished it, grudgingly, but this is also my favorite genre, I can't get enough space merc sims. And I do feel guilty ripping up someone's labor of love, it just doesn't excuse some poor choices that unforgivably damage what was almost a really good indy game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969831909', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 833, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 799, 'last_played': 1710813501}

author: {'steamid': '76561197983728415', 'num_games_owned': 199, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 692, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 643, 'last_played': 1684583776}
review:
Really enjoyed this game, was worth every penny. You can definitely see that the developers put a lot of effort and love in to the game.
If you have enjoyed any of these games then you will definitely enjoy this one:
- Space Quest
- Space Pirates and Zombies
- Escape Velocity
- Elite

Things that I found great about the game

+ Really fun game play
+ Open world galaxy
+ Plenty of funny moments and funny story
+ Lots to do if you don't rush the main story
+ Quite a number of upgrades for the ships and plenty of different ships to purchase and fly.
+ Awesome soundtrack, every song is an ear worm :)
+ Great references to tons of classic games spanning the 80's and 90's

Items that were not so great

- Not a lot of replayability, therefore don't rush the main story

author: {'steamid': '76561198018323262', 'num_games_owned': 1088, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 136, 'last_played': 1564782615}
review:
Bought it due to steam suggestions, advertised "Full controller support" and raging reviews.

"Full controller support" is absolutely misleading and if this wasn't an indie game, I would have refunded it. I was not able to start a game on my <insert TV streaming device> until I connected a keyboard. The controller support is clearly a tacked-on afterthought since many keybindings are ridiculously overcomplicated (a simple thing like e.g. "open map" should not require 2 button presses.)

Gameplay-wise, the other negative reviews are pretty much spot on. The mission selection is poor and repetitive, ship customisation is lackluster and combat simple and uninvolving. If you are only after the RPG/adventure part of it, then it may be good enough for you.

It will forever remain a puzzle to me how this is "overwhelmingly positive" on steam..

author: {'steamid': '76561198050281660', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1798, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1798, 'last_played': 1549160927}
review:
My favorite recent iteration of the elite-style space opera flight sim game.  In most regards, it is similar to the vintage "Escape Velocity" games, but with a single story arc.  It is highly enjoyable, funny, and addictive.

The crux of the game involves buying space ships, and doing missions involving passengers, cargo, or combat.  It's a 2-dimensional game, so much less difficult than similarly themed games in 3D like Elite.  And there is a galaxy-wide conflict story arc.
