author: {'steamid': '76561198045380427', 'num_games_owned': 4982, 'num_reviews': 513, 'playtime_forever': 519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 242, 'last_played': 1544331468}
review:
[code][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/33025671-Missi-the-Achievement-Huntress/] Please see my curator page for more games that are worth your time [/url][/code]

Info Game: 
This is an open world space exploration game. Your new bought space ship is reported stolen and so the police take it away and give you a mini ship. You try to earn money with doing different kind of task. Selling items, be a taxi for different people, clean up space junk and attack pirates. That way you try to buy a bigger ship so you can earn even more money at the same time. The story is funny and you have different dialog options.  

Info achievements:
You have achievements for party of the story, but there are also a lot of achievements for doing the different tasks. Those seems a bit grindy, especially to get to 100 million money.  You can complte this game between 25 and 35 hours. 

Pros & Cons:
+ I like the open world with different missions
+ The characters seems funny and each have their own character
- Achievements seems doable but a bit too grindy

author: {'steamid': '76561197984975140', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1373, 'last_played': 1543294692}
review:
TLDR: 3030 Deathwar Redux is a definate buy for those that love games like the X series, Elite Dangerous, and Star Citizen, and enjoy 90's throwbacks.

3030 Deathwar Redux is a charming little 90's throwback space adventure with a surprising amount of depth, ultimately allowing you to play how you want. You can choose a number of different ways to make money(pirating, salvaging, mining, trading, bounty hunting, missions), and they all are viable, and are balanced fairly well.  There are probably 5-10 different mission types, from towing a container, to killing a pirate they are pretty well varied.    

There are a fair amount of ships 20-30 over all you can purchase and all have their niches to support how you want to play the game, and probably 40-50 upgrades which are released throughout your 15-20 hours playing through the story.  There are a number of system upgrades (ecm, boost, cargo scanner, fuel scoop, asteroid scanner, etc) that you can purchase which they are both intuitive, easy to use, and ultimately better the over all experience.  

One of the highlights was the universe design; ultimatley you have one large map, and individual solar systems within the map.  In between solar systems (deepspace) you have a nebula that damage your ship if you drive through them.  So ultimately you can go anywhere within the map (universe) and even drop out of FTL in deepspace.  When you hit the gravitational boundry of a solar system it slows your FTL drive down considerably.  Overall the map design is solid, and how the environment interacts with your ship feels great. 

UI was also designed very well, it's non invasive and appears only when required.  It also gives you a solid understanding of the situtation with very little required from the user, which is ultimately the halmark of solid UI design.  

The core gameplay is top down view on your ship, game play in this mode is responsive and the systems work really well toghether(ecm, FTL, tractorbeam, etc).  The secondary game play is the side scrolling aspect which ocurs within salvaging, space stations, and on some planets within the main storyline.  This is an area that while not terrible could probably use a bit more work, for example when you pull your side arm you stop and cannot move.  It just feels clunky in comparison to the rest of the game which is well polished. 

The universe for the most part does feel alive and lived in.  There are ships flying around in system, miners mining, police, moneyball races, all add to the feeling of the universe being lived in and alive.  There are a few random events that occur in system such as distress beacons ships about to explode, but this could definately be increased.  The distress beacon definately isn't really explained very well and is on a timer, and ultimately each ship I encountered ended up blowing up. 

Overall 3030 Deathwar Redux is a great game, and I highly suggest it if you enjoy games such as Elite Dangerous, Star Citizen, and the X series.  The developers state this was a labor of love over 10 years, and I don't doubt it, its a solid well designed game, and ultimately it's a lot of fun. 

What I would love to see in 3030 Deathwar Redux 2: 
Emergent dynamic gameplay, a reason to stay in the universe after the story ends.  
Factions, with dynamic waring parties.
Construction, X series style construction and fleet construction would be amazing.
Destructable bases/space ports.   
Greater dynamic event diversity with greater scale, faction wars, invations etc..

author: {'steamid': '76561198056389001', 'num_games_owned': 238, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35, 'last_played': 1541807075}
review:
C'mon! It's a retro adventure game!
Who didn't enjoy the old days playing Monkey Island 1 and 2? Or Legend of Kyrandia? Or Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis? Beneath a Steel Sky/Prisoner of Ice (can't remember the 1st of the saga, something blablabla Comet?)? Full Throttle? Or... Or... Or... There were way too many AWESOME adventure games back in the day! And this is a throwback to those days! In space! Who doesn't like space? Be like Han Solo and explore the universe on your own spaceship! Besides, the game even has a workshop! 
Give this game a spin! You might like it. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198030969440', 'num_games_owned': 329, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 943, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 541, 'last_played': 1642469069}
review: Anyone looking for a nostalgia trip back to the days of Escape Velocity should grab this game. Only it's not just Escape Velocity, it's also part LucasArts too. 3030 Deathwar Redux is like the best 90s game you never got to play. The writing is hilarious and the little details are delightful. The game immediately feels like an old friend you want to grab a beer with, then get lunch with, then invite over, until your old friend just moves in and makes himself at home.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070742314', 'num_games_owned': 944, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 6448, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2659, 'last_played': 1562440666}

There are courier runs, transport runs, trading , bounty hunting, pirating, conspiracy, excellent derelict exploration, quests, mining, etc.  Ships support fast transport, bulky mining careers, military expeditions all to the good. Love the fact that playing tips don't flash by way too fast but pause for you to absorb unlike other games

review:
Utterly fantastic. Fulfills my spaceship captaining fantasies totally, despite only being 2D. Great universe to explore, great mechanics. Trading and smuggling felt a bit lackluster, but piracy, combat and even mining felt good. Comabt is simple but works nicely and is fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014356155', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1244, 'last_played': 1543190962}
review: A fun game with a lot of humor.  It has a fairly straightforward storyline, but you can take as much time as you want to make money for upgrading your ship: courier/taxi jobs, trading, bounties, mining, salvaging, pirating. There's just something so great about flying around a galaxy with an 80s synth-pop soudtrack, stopping in at space stations and engaging in "space banter" with creatively-named lifeforms.  It has a great 70s/80s sci-fi atmosphere, which is reinforced by the lo-fi graphics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004994551', 'num_games_owned': 394, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 972, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 972, 'last_played': 1543481819}
review:
A retro joy - So much fun, a great value. I took a chance on this game at 50% on recent steam sale -Bird in Sky really nailed it, for me as an adult gamer where time is my most limited resource. If you like space exploration/adventure it's hard to go wrong with this one.

What I liked about it:
-Aesthetics & pacing - The 2D Vector mechanic really reminded me of Grand Theft Auto 2- Due to the simplicity of the controls, you can really get into action very quickly.
-80's Retro futuristic vibe with so many loving fan-culture references. Likewise the synth-pop soundtrack takes you back in time.
-Intuitive controls, which just work. The learning curve of controls and exposure to new mechanics is fast, steady and engages you.
-Space-Adventure RPG progression, with considerably less serious grind mechanic than Elite. You can take on whatever mission types you want, and your profit margins aren't too tight. Typical missions can be completed in 2-4 minutes- Much less of a sense of waiting to travel between systems than say Elite.
-Adventure-lite game mechanic - This draws strongly on Lucasarts influences, although the writing quality felt a bit amateur.


What could be better:
-Ship design balance - For combat and most missions 've been playing, high engine power and turn radius were critical features - and one of the first ships in the game has no rivals on these dimensions. I felt like main plot milk runs and combat doesn't reward you much to experiment with alternate styles of midrange ships, until you've unlocked rather high spec ships. 
-Space station layouts and Salvage locations looked distinctive, but quickly felt repetitive. Note: Elite Dangerous, a much grander title has very similar limitation.

Good job to Bird in Sky and Crunchy Leaf on this - you should be proud of yourselves.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061336689', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 152, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1543736574}

author: {'steamid': '76561198024324687', 'num_games_owned': 319, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 655, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 655, 'last_played': 1543342931}
review:
A true hidden gem - I didn't know how badly I needed this game in my life until I played it!
Lots of different ways to go about earning your space bucks, lots of ships, lots of weapons, lots of upgrades and a pretty sizable map to explore. And they didn't blow it out of proportion just for the sake of making travelling a giant timesink á la Elite - thank god.

If the trailer even remotely seems interesting, pick it up - especially during a sale. I'm sure I'll be able to sink quite a few hours into this one. Highly recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561197972446918', 'num_games_owned': 137, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 322, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 254, 'last_played': 1639791037}

author: {'steamid': '76561198010734204', 'num_games_owned': 391, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 770, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 770, 'last_played': 1543630548}
review:
I initially stayed away because of the graphics, but, as with most games, once you get into it, they don't matter too much. I wouldn't say that they grew on me, but the game is a bit deeper than the graphics make it look.

So, what's the game like? It's actually very similar to Rebel Galaxy, except of course for the combat, which is more like a shallower, more fast-paced EV Nova.

I've mentioned depth already, and that's because the whole game is shallower than I'd expected. There are maybe 6 or 10 different randomly generated side mission types, but I only tried 2 or 3 because there was no point in doing any other types. The only thing to grind for is money - no reputation or anything, and that's fine with me, but it does limit the variety of mission rewards and lead to "what mission type is the easiest for the most money, and let's do that one only." Money is pretty hard to come by, since the missions barely scale with your progression; at the start, you'll make maybe 6k credits per mission, and at the end, most of the missions will give 20-30k...and the best ships cost around 6 million. There's no particular reason to get the best ships, so it's not *really* a problem, but it just feels kind of hollow. It doesn't help that the missions don't particularly ramp up in difficulty. You won't see anything like Rebel Galaxy's "penetrate a blockade" or "survive a delivery". 

I didn't bother trying to trade, since the game map is rather annoying to use and doesn't show discovered prices or let you make trade routes. 

So, that was a lot of complaining...BUT I still recommend the game. I had more fun than I have with most games. Combat, while nothing more than "hold down spacebar and dodge enemy fire", was enjoyable. Upgrading my ship was enjoyable. Most of all, the writing was funny and engaging, and struck just the right amount of silliness without becoming ridiculous (although there were a lot of spelling mistakes). And, in a way, I'm glad that the game didn't have too many complex systems, because depth can actually get in the way of itself and make a game overwhelming (eg Space Rangers). 

Thumbs up. I wish it had a little more meat, but 12 hours of playtime for $7.50 was more than worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970316122', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 823, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 757, 'last_played': 1546054570}

author: {'steamid': '76561197968312284', 'num_games_owned': 2395, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1147, 'last_played': 1566202583}
review:
[b]Recipe:[/b] How to Create a great 2D Space Exploration Game 
[u]Ingredients:[/u]
1 cup of [b]creative and active Devs[/b]
1 cup of [b]Elite[/b]
3 tablespoons of [b]90'S Lucasarts Adventures flair and humour[/b]
4 teaspoons of [b]Space, Pirates and Zombies[/b]
4 tablespoons of [b]great Soundtrack[/b]
3 teaspoons of [b]customization options[/b]
Put all the ingredients in a bowl and stir together until you have 3030 Deathwar Redux. (Don't forget the workshop topping!)

Meet John Falcon, a mixture of Indiana Jones and Han Solo and help him getting through his adventure. 
You are free to choose your path - will you be a trader? Hunt down Pirates? Space Taxi Driver? 
As it's an open world 2D Elite exploration game, you don't have to choose. 
The visuals are very well done and together with the great soundtrack (Instrumental + The Kyoto Connection), the game delivers a great retro-esque atmosphere.
The gameplay is really fun and as the game offers loads of customization options, the fun doesn't stop after you played through the initial quest. I am not through the game yet, as I am on my way saving money to get an even better ship plus upgrades. 
The devs are very active and responding, adding new features and getting rid of bugs all the time. 
For this reason, 3030 Deathwar Redux gets my vote for the "Labor of Love" Award 2018. I hope the devs will continue their journey through space with us, so I can nominate this game in 2019 also!

The Kyoto Connection sums it up nicely in one of their songs:
♫[i]You need to play this game if you want to stay alive[/i]♬

author: {'steamid': '76561198016331464', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 858, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 858, 'last_played': 1535396080}
review:
Návykové RPG s geniální retro grafikou. Návrat do mého dětství - pixelová grafika a 2D prostředí.
Příběh s nádechem černého humoru a kromě hlavní náplně jsou tu i vedlejší kratochvíle (mojí nejoblíbenější je nakopávání droidů). A pak tu je známá klasika - těžba surovin, plnění misí, lovení pirátů - aby člověk měl 
Cestování vesmírem není omezeno na pouhé lety branami, ale člověk musí vést svoji loď nebezpečnými nástrahami vesmíru a někdy se jim i nejlépe obloukem vyhnout.

Zábava na dlouhé večery - za mě 9/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050576791', 'num_games_owned': 389, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1107, 'last_played': 1542876843}
review:
Dwuwymiarowy SpaceSim, w założeniach rozgrywki podobny do Space Rangers 2.
Jako pilot statku kosmicznego podróżujemy między układami gwiezdnymi, dokujemy na stacjach kosmicznych, gdzie możemy podejmować się rozmaitych misji od kurierskich i przewozu pasażerów po zlecenia na likwidację piratów, co prowadzi do walki w kosmosie. Na stacjach możemy też kupić nowy statek wybierając z szerokiej puli jednostek o różnym przeznaczeniu, od myśliwców najlepszych do walki, szybkie statki kurierskie lub wolne transportowce o sporej ładowności.
3030 Deathwar Redux ma też własny system ekonomiczny, poza wykonywaniem misji możemy kursować między stacjami i handlować towarami. 
Jest też możliwość eksploatacji systemu gwiezdnego w poszukiwaniu wraków rozbitych statków kosmicznych. Gdy znajdziemy taki wrak rozgrywka zamienia się w specjalną minigrę w której nasz pilot w skafandrze kosmicznym przeszukuje pokład bezpańskiego wraku.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970359298', 'num_games_owned': 292, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2029, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 39, 'last_played': 1637759874}
review:
What a great little gem. Found this game by accident and I'm glad I did. Its a cracking throwback to the oldschool PC retro era were gameplay was simple and fun.  

The game is a 2D perspective space sim/adventure game and it does an awesome job of combining the best elements of both. 

There is a slight learning curve at the start when discovering the core gameplay mechanics but once you have flown around the starting system you will pick it up easily enough.

If you are a fan of space sims/RPG's/point and click adventure games or even classic 80's arcade shooters you will find something to like playing this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042722153', 'num_games_owned': 670, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1118, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1118, 'last_played': 1542728483}
review: What can I say about 3030 Deathwar Redux. I liked it a lot! It felt a little unpolished in certain places, but it was full of humor, action, and charm where it counts. The only downside I can mention is that the campaign is rather short, and if you focus solely on that you'll find yourself wanting for more. Lots of clever dialogue and pop culture references to be found, and an overall competent top-down space shooter. The side-scrolling parts are an interesting inclusion, and thankfully the options are pretty forgiving, because the default walk speed for these sections is rather slow. I'd like to see more content in the future, and want more reasons to keep playing this wonderful game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978203764', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 288, 'last_played': 1549280532}

author: {'steamid': '76561197983353671', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 186, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 186, 'last_played': 1543010540}
review:
First off, developer is asking for "five star" reviews which is always a warning sign for me. If its really great, you don't have to guilt people into it.

Now this is a 2d space shooter with a bit of trading and generic missions (go and kill, taxi, delivery boy, etc) thrown in. Main character has been blatantly ripped off from old Lucasarts games. In fact the whole "adventure" interface looks like 80s adventure games, at least after they got VGA face-lift. Unfortunately the adventure bit is more or less chatting to random npcs with random lines in generic 1-screen space stations.

The whole thing gives me 90s shareware game vibe. If you want 2d space shoot-em-up, space pirates and zombies is wastly prettier with tons of different ship types to whack. For generic delivery boy missions with occasional slightly scripted one, that goes down to just about every pc open end space game written.  It'd be unfair to compare to Elite:Dangerous but the structure is fairly similar.

I'm sure the story picks up a little bit but I just can't muster interest to keep on going. Got 1st ship upgrade with decent cargo hold, turret, warp drive etc for around 90k, that probably would take you a fair bit ahead. Did a bit of travel between systems but the other systems are pretty much exactly the same.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993475888', 'num_games_owned': 866, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 324, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 324, 'last_played': 1542332651}
review:
[h1]Introduction:[/h1]
‘3030 Deathwar redux – A Space Odyssey’ is quite immersive 2D space humorous arcade game about a pilot adventurer who happened to appear in a wrong place at a wrong time. Surprisingly enough, despite its initially simple nature, game feels quite deep, with a lot of text content, various jobs, side quests and interesting choice of vocal music.

 [h1]The story and game universe:[/h1]
Actual story starts at year 3029, with your alter ego, John Falcon, working as a random freelancer. The game universe is full of abandoned, or crashed ships and stations, which can be easily accessed and searched for some valuable loot. By the start of the game, your character managed to gather a working crew, collect quite some money and purchased new ship. However quite soon it turns out that the ship he purchased, was stolen, with previous owner’s body found dead inside. Local police force provides John with basic ship to travel within the system limits and some spare credits as a compensation, while investigation is going on.

Universe itself is full of many tiny details, which you find out through rumors and dialogues, or through various magazines. For example, most of the pilots are unable to land on planets, which leads them to having complications in getting coffee, or bath. This is why you can meet one of cruise liners in space, which serve as something similar to our ocean cruise ships, with full spectrum of entertainment on board. Or you can meet a space trucker, who carries huge amount of cargo. So much so that it resembles more of a train, than a spaceship honestly. And I didn’t even cover bars at local space stations where you can land, talk to random pilots, or take jobs. So yeah, as you understand, the universe itself is quite rich lore-wise.

[h1]Gameplay analysis:[/h1]
As it was mentioned in the introduction part, ‘Deathwar’ is 2D space adventure, which means that most of the time you’ll view your ship from top-down point of view. Landing on space stations, or abandoned vessels, though, switches you to the side 2D perspective. In terms of tone overall, game feels like those quests from ‘90s, so if you enjoyed, say, “Space Quest”, maybe you’ll like this atmosphere too.

Perhaps the best part about the game is the amount of possible secondary missions, which surely counts a dozen of different jobs, to say the least. Most of them mean that you’ll just need to go from point A to point B, though, but wide variety of ships you can pilot, makes you capable of immersing into your secondary role. Do you enjoy delivering cargo? Get a vessel which is capable of pulling many tons of cargo. Prefer working as a taxi driver? Feel free to buy yourself a space bus. Yes, an actual bus without wheels. 

Quite often you’ll find yourself trying to fit your ship for multiple roles at same time, though. It’s nothing bad really, but keep in mind that in many cases when buying a new ship, you’ll need to sacrifice something, in order to get bonuses for something else, that you need more. So, as you can see, the choice can be quite tough sometimes, especially given the fact that there are multiple dozen different ships, or even more, who knows...

As we started talking about the ships, I couldn’t just refrain from devoting another paragraph to their upgrades. There are so many upgrades for the ship, so that some “Pimp my ride” show can easily die of jealousy. Missiles? Throttle boost? Shields? Mines? Cargo or ship scanners? Literally anything one’s soul might want. But yeah, most of those upgrades tend to appear with time, so you’ll have to stick to very basic stuff during first hours.

 [h1]Visuals:[/h1]
Cheapish looking graphics. Truth to be said, though – game looks like that [i]intentionally[/i], however I couldn’t help but smirk few times at start. That first reaction tends to pass with time though. You just need to get used to the game style.

Perhaps, ‘Deathwar’ can be called retro futuristic in some way, as game literally copies most of our everyday objects, adds up some futuristic details to them and just drags it into the game! There are some exceptions to that rule, of course, but you’ll get my idea once you’ll see flying police Chevrolet corvette without two-flags sign and wheels.

Overall, though, game looks interesting and quite variative: here you can see a huge shuttle at the space, which looks even more gigantic, compared to your first vessel. Yet at the next moment you land at space station, go to the bar and you can see usual ‘small’ cars, which size doesn’t look so tiny anymore. On contraty, you find them quite big too! 

Another paragraph, perhaps, would be devoted to the scavenging abandoned vessels and stations, as it’s fully working side-game with separate mechanics, where you jump into a space suit and explore various blown up debris, while trying to recover the bodies of possible survivors, loot some crates and shooting whatever hostiles are present on the ship. Not all life forms you meet are dangerous, though. Some of them can charge up your suit with extra energy. Overall, this mechanic, despite being done in rather simplish way, feels quite interesting and alone manages to diversify the gameplay.

[h1]The sound:[/h1]
Music in the game feels quite cool. Surprisingly enough, songs with female vocalist make you wanna stay in space for one more minute, just for the sake of listening the song till the end. Other, non-vocal songs are pleasant to listen too, of course. In all honesty, game should have the OST as a separate DLC.

Other sounds, like blaster shooting, or engine throttling, etc. feel usual and moderate every game ones, which is neither good nor a bad thing. So yeah, overall sound in ‘Deathwar’ isn’t something people usually complain on.

[i]With all that being said, let’s take a brief look at strong and weak sides of the game and come up with final verdict….[/i]

[h1]PRO’s:[/h1]
[b]-Funky, humorous style:[/b]
Game likes to bring various jokes during dialogues and overall it not even trying to look serious. Do you often see humorous space games? Neither do I.
[b]-The universe is rich for lore and events:[/b]
You can even easily meet a bounty hunter who would come up with a suggestion to secure your ship, but take any bounty for his kills… And run away as soon as he sees real space pirates. Or not… And it’s literally just one of many other events which bring so much life to the game.
[b]-Large variety of secondary jobs:[/b]
You can be almost anything, from standard bounty-hunter, delivery guy, or truck & bus driver, to professional trash-shooter, or even spy-style photo agent. It’s all in your hands.

[h1]CON’s and issues:[/h1]
[b]-Weak tutorial:[/b]
Basically, you quickly forget what was shown in the tutorial and then have to re-discover how some things work. Just remember that game doesn’t have controls change option yet, so F1 key is your best helper in some situations.
[b]-Clunky space combat:[/b]
Maybe on higher tier levels it’s different, but on lower tiers you simply can’t turn your gun as a turret, and have to turn whole ship if you want to aim at the enemy. That mechanic adds up ‘interesting’ gameplay, where you feel like you’re playing 16-bit space arcade, rather than modern indie game.
[b]-Odd map navigation:[/b]
Navigation in this game is overcomplicated, as universe and local star system maps are done in somewhat clunky way.

[h1]The conclusion:[/h1]
Overall, ‘3030 Deathwar Redux - a Space Odyssey’ is quite interesting game with large variety of quests and side jobs for your choice, many lines of funky dialogues and a deep role immersing system. If you have weak PC or working laptop, this game will surely brighten up your days with fun, humorous gameplay.

[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/23741321/]Follow our curator page,[b] Alexander's Club Curations[/b] if you like and want to see more reviews like this one.[/url][/quote]

author: {'steamid': '76561198214392393', 'num_games_owned': 318, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1548155746}
review:
3030 Deathwar is a space sim, a genre I haven't really touched for over a year now.  There seems to be a lot to do in this game, but thankfully, you're not overwhelmed by it all, rather you're gradually introduced to the mechanics, making Deathwar more welcoming to new players to the genre, though I do still think that one or two things could have been made clearer.

Check out my first impressions of the game here:  https://youtu.be/KkxhAyObtB4

For more reviews, as well as Let's Plays, check out Gemini Does Games on Youtube, Twitch, and Patreon!

author: {'steamid': '76561198005194478', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 442, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 442, 'last_played': 1542516829}
review:
Took a while for me to finally play it, but now since I have, not a bad game as all. As the info states it's a hybrid space sim/adventure game... 

The last patch helped out a with the space sim part as there a tons of ships available now in a pretty cool interface that reminds me of Space Rangers 2 a bit.... Is this a graphic intensive game, not at all, but it has it's own style which is pretty cool, heh. 

The soundtrack is awesome as well, has a lot of 80s vibe music when going around space and the pop culture and story bit seems pretty cool as well. 

If anything the only real complaint I have is you can't change any of the keybinds at all, which for lefties like me is a pain, luckily I can just go the auto-hot key route to get the keys where I want them too, but I honestly hate doing that and it always strikes me as odd when you don't get keybind options for the controls. 

Space Combat feels more like a rails shooter in a way, but overall there's not much tactics involved with it seems, just turn and manuever until you get lucky with good shots to take down the ship or ships attacking you. There is also slight grind in terms of trying to upgrade your ships and all, but it hasn't bothered me at all yet. 

I haven't really gotten involved in mining parts of the game yet, but I have done the savalaging of direlect ships, and overall that's pretty cool as well.. There doesn't seem to be any interesting gear or ship upgrades to find while savalaging at least from what i've done at first, so it's been more of a helpful Money Sink to get in a abaondon ship, and come out with a few cargo items to sell and good cash too, so we'll see if that changes as the game goes on. 

So, if you're bored waiting for the next big blockbuster and feel like trying out something new, it's well worth giving it a go.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961489779', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 706, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 706, 'last_played': 1552409834}
review: This is a surprisingly-deep, fun game, full of exploration, fights against space pirates, and adventure- and the plot and writing are dry, witty and occasionally very funny.  If you liked Escape Velocity, Starsector or other open-world RPGs, you'll like this.  WIth improved modding support and other features now being added, this game looks like it might really go somewhere great.  Give it a go; it's easily worth the asking price.

review: This game rocks, takes me back to them Escape Velocity days!  But Better!

author: {'steamid': '76561198011830301', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1069, 'last_played': 1542306867}
review:
It's worth the price. The setting feels fun and the music helps to enhance it. It feels like a more accessible, top-down EVE Online, X-series game, et cetera. Yet it also has a new retro wave feel to it, too.

Combat is simple but enjoyable, while the upgrade system is exciting and had me eager to return to dock to check for new upgrades.

My only current complaint might be longevity, but like... that's pretty minor.

Recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561198083114199', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3959, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3939, 'last_played': 1542386598}
review: I took my time and completed the main story in 63 hours.  Steam price is $14.99.  But buy when it's on sale for $10 or less because of its short duration.  Very addictive for a 2D space game.  Good music.  Good selection of ships and weapons upgrades.  Mission tasks are varied:  tractor containers, deliver packages, transport passengers, take photographs, eliminate space junk, eradicate criminals.  Various cut scenes.  A couple planet visits occur but there is no planet exploration.  There are many space stations having handfuls of people you may talk to.  All dialogue is text-only with humorous undertones.  Mining asteroids is possible.  Exploration of derelict ships, mapping out hull-damaging nebulae and rapid space flight ability add to the charm.  Keyboard mapping is okay but the user cannot remap keys.  No pause feature.  To game save, you must be at a station with no pending missions.  I've spent hundreds of hours in the 3D X-series games by Egosoft and was amazed that this 2D game could be as compelling to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980585496', 'num_games_owned': 409, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 1835, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1745, 'last_played': 1642327537}
review:
Flew a hospital full of chocolate into a space war.
Worth every penny!
The first fifteen minutes of this game had me wondering, its nothing great to look at, but thats its only flaw.
Missions, Trading, Story, Looting Wrecks, Bounty Hunting, Mining, all in more ships than you can shake a stick at. The story adds features as it progresses and gently pushes you towards finding even more.

If you at all like space and sandbox games, this will please you no end. 
And I really have to mention the soundtrack, which is outstanding.

In 20 hours of play I have noticed only one bug, some sound effects sometimes dissapear, and I dont know what triggers it, restarting the game fixes it. Fortunely this doesnt effect the epic music, so I generally dont mind xD

If you buy an indie game this year, this is a worthy purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073629871', 'num_games_owned': 331, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 346, 'last_played': 1596139859}

author: {'steamid': '76561197989313458', 'num_games_owned': 280, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 839, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 648, 'last_played': 1543339242}
review: I have been pleasantly surprised by the depth and breadth of this game, and by how much fun it is.  It merges two genres I've known and loved for decades - top down space shooter/exploration, and third person adventure game.  Think of the humor and old-school adventure game style of the Space Quest games, combined with the open world space trading and combat of Drox Operative.  The game is full of surprises, and thus far the story has taken two turns I didn't see coming, and I'm only a fraction of the way through.  The soundtrack is fantastic, and really adds atmosphere to the experience of cruising around space completing missions and exploring wrecks.  10/10, I highly recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067725186', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 1197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1197, 'last_played': 1542838779}
review:
This is an interesting game. I feel like it would be the type of game I'd make if I knew how to make video games. I'd start with a list of desires, incorporate them into the game, and then pray they all worked well together.

What does this game have?
- Great music, but the number of tracks is limited so you'll hear many repeated.
- Clever game settings which control if songs switch when entering a new area. It is great to have this control.
- Several types of missions to earn money.
- Lots of ships and ship equipment to purchase.
- Space battles
- Open gameplay [/list]

The game is fun. I completed it in about 15 hours over the span of a weekend. It can tend to get a bit grindy as you complete jobs to earn money for ships, ship equipment, and ship repairs. But, you don't need the best ship to win this game, I suspect it can be won with almost any ship.

If there is a Deathwar 4040 in the works, I'd offer these suggestions:
-Don't limit the ships/upgrades available to the level of the story. I flew clear across the galaxy to find better equipment early in the game. It did not exist. Every system sold the same gear. New/better gear only arrived as the story progressed.

- The game spans a galaxy, but every station visited was essentially a duplicate. There was no feeling of scale or change.

- Keep the ship/equipment upgrade system. Being able to sell and change ships/equipment without huge penalties makes it more fun to experiment with different ship types.

- More, and varied jobs would be great. Current jobs are all are quite similar. The one unique job was Untangle the Circuit. It was one of the best jobs since it paid well, and could be completed without a lot of travel.

- Some game elements are "hidden". I was nearly 10 hours into the game before I found the little challenges about visiting 10 systems, visiting all the systems, and the badge/medal system for salvage.

- Look at that, I even nominated this game for an award, and updated my review for the 2018 Autum sale badge requirements.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010637556', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 851, 'last_played': 1542604505}
review: I very rarely review games, but this game deserves it. I've played any number of open-world space games over the past 20 years and end up hoping for more than is delivered - this one is the exception - deep, varied, hilarious dialogue, fantastic music - I'm enjoying every minute of it. 12/10 would buy again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069994429', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 779, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 779, 'last_played': 1541967049}
review:
3030 Deathwar Redux is a short and somewhat flawed but generally good space adventure game. In theory, there are several playstyles (miner, trader, taxi / delivery man, salvager, bounty hunter, pirate, etc.) but many of them are painful. Mining is very boring, and perhaps more importantly you'll need a large amount of cargo space to make money without frequent, tedious trips back to the station - cargo space that you probably won't be able to afford at the beginning of the game. Salvaging is less boring but has the same problem with cargo space. Trading has the same problem, and worse, there's no way to know what the prices of goods are at various stations unless you visit them all and write them down on a piece of paper or something, making it a real pain to find a trade route. Bounty hunting requires decent weapons which you won't have at the beginning, and the missions are rarely offered. Piracy practically limits you to the very few systems with pirate bases, which are mostly on the other side of the known universe and inaccessible at the start of the game. So you'll probably be a taxi / delivery man for much of the game, which is not a bad job but it doesn't pay well and gets old.

Besides those problems, the gameplay is pretty good. Combat is relatively fun, talking to bar patrons is interesting in the beginning, and the game has a lot of charm. One weird thing is that combat-wise your $100,000 ship from the beginning of the game is about equally strong as the $2,000,000 ship you can get near the end because all ships get only one weapon. (Some can equip two weapons, but then each one deals half damage...) The main difference is the number of missiles, but missiles are too expensive to use often and if you're good with the gun you won't need them anyway. Some more differentiation would have helped me feel like I was actually making progress. For instance, if tier-2 ships were restricted to tier-2 (and below) weapons and upgrades, then upgrading your ship would actually matter. As it is, I used the same gun from about the beginning of the game all the way to the end and only ever upgraded my fighter to get more cargo space.

The graphics are poor, but they're good enough and more importantly they're stylish. The music isn't great but it's decent; it was produced by The Kyoto Connection, which releases all their music free for use in all kinds of projects, which is a nice idea. The controls are obnoxious if you don't use a QWERTY keyboard or otherwise don't use the WASD setup, since the game doesn't support key rebinding. I recommend the keyboard + mouse as the most effective control scheme.

The game takes about 10 hours to get through if you don't do any grinding. Overall, it's a fun little game that's worth buying (perhaps on sale, given how short it is) if you like the genre (and aren't hoping to be a trader) but it has some annoyances that prevent it from being great.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968589305', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 1838, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1644, 'last_played': 1542640805}
review:
There's something about this game that really charms me. The simplistic and retro art style may fool you into thinking that this is a primitive game but I found the gameplay surprisingly polished. Probably because they apparently spent 10 years polishing and cutting things that didn't add to the experience. There's a lighthearted cliche story to keep things going and motivate you to get out and explore, but instead of just forcing you into impossible situations that can only be solved with grinding, this game actually helps you along quite nicely. Trading upgrades/weapons etc is done in a way that rewards experimentation rather than punishing it: The price is the same for buying and selling. Very simple, very effective. The result is a game where you have the freedom to just jump in, play it your own way, take your time or rush towards the end of the story. Some will probably find the game too easy, for me it was just perfect but then again maybe I just got lucky... I went with an all-round ship with an ion cannon, hard to aim but capable of one-shotting the weaker enemies. There are LOTS of other ship types and weapons to experiment with so you're almost guaranteed to find something that suits you.

Having grown up with computer games in the mid-80s, the soundtrack alone was worth the price TBH. A brilliant choice by the devs.

Finally, I strongly recommend reading the player made guide over at the Community Hub. The in-game "radar" can be tricky to make out at first but becomes super useful once you know how to read it.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1374528312

author: {'steamid': '76561198020440057', 'num_games_owned': 1041, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 894, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 894, 'last_played': 1541894153}
review:
I believe I paid the full $14.99 for this a while back and just now got around to actually playing through the whole game. All in all I definitely recommend it and even more so when it's on sale (like it is at the time of me writing this review). Sort of a 2D Freelancer-type game. Good for those that don't want to put the time and effort into something like Elite but still want similar gameplay mechanics.

Pros:
- Good overall gameplay
- Fun dialogue
- Variety of neat minigame type things to do

Cons:
- Not as deep as I'd like it to be. I only owned like two ships throughout the game and only upgraded my weapon once. Still easily beat the game.
- $15 for 15 hours of gameplay is a little steep for me but oh well
- Going along the same lines as above - not a ton of replay value, at least for myself.

I enjoyed the game. I love the style and idea. I'm happy to have supported the developers. However, I do wish there was a bit more to the game and significantly more reason to come back and play again. On sale though, it's a steal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049447848', 'num_games_owned': 717, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 581, 'last_played': 1587465511}

review: A fantastic little game. Lots of movie references that made me chuckle, some fun music tunes that you have the in-game option of removing if you desire and the freedom to earn credits for bigger and better ships by doing anything from taxiing people across the stars, fighting pirates, clearing space junk, mining ore and more. review: This is an absolutely stellar pixel-art game.  The gameplay is fun, the customization out of this world, and the humor witty and biting.  The whole universe comes alive very nicely and I foresee hours of fun.  You can really tell that the devs put a lot of work into making this an immersive and deep experience.  Speaking of the Devs, I had an installation problem and reached out to them via EM.  Had a reply and a fix in less than 10 minutes.  So they are very active and very customer friendly.  I would heartily recommend this game!

review: Awesome game, well worth the price! Brings back old school space exploration feel. May look cheap but inside the 2.5D is a living galaxy of fun! Random missions to take, aliens to meet in bars, or kill in bounties. You can even just explore derelects and be a space taxi if thats your thing. Writing is great, stereotype "space cowboy" but thats part of the humor, which has a lot of sci-fi satire! Overall well put together game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990395265', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 1277, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 976, 'last_played': 1585019111}
review: Bought this game a while ago, after some friend's recommendation. Its a good take on the classic top-down space ship piloting game with some adventure elements thrown in. The Sound track is FANTASTIC and the game has some very funny and clever moments. Recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561198257054043', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 155, 'last_played': 1667750067}
review:
Being a fan of games from the 90's, this has that classic feel and at the same time being very smooth, humorous and enjoyable. I've only started to get into this game, but really enjoy all aspects so far. There is a bit of reading of dialog and taking directions, so be prepared for an emersive story, not just fast action. 

I'd buy this game at full price, so if it's on sale - jump on it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197961125313', 'num_games_owned': 1018, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1381, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1269, 'last_played': 1554251263}
review:
I've had much fun with 3030, and with this latest big update, I'm back for more. There's plenty to do here: Wanna haul passengers from system to system? Got that covered. Wanna run bounties and kill some pixelly baddies? Check! Search through wreckage for loot and bodies? Why not? Mining? Sure! Tractor beam some boxes across half the galaxy? Ok! 

In addition to all of these, there is a storyline to follow, a sidekick to pickup, and many areas to explore. Also, your exploits are set to soundtrack out of an '80s movie.
Get this and enjoy!

author: {'steamid': '76561198032396835', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 451, 'last_played': 1542141046}
review: I continue to play and get drawn into the games story and antics. The game's well written and reminds me more of old school JRPGs in that it's heavily story driven. I can't wait to see what they devs do next.

review:
Excellent game. I've seen many sci-fi pop culture reference that have made me chuckle, the soundtrack is phenomenal and the core game play is solid, you can choose to ignore the story line for the most part and just live the life of a bounty hunter/miner/ship salvager/pirate/taxi driver/ and other jobs in between.  The story is well written in a light hearted manner.

Overall very worth the price of admission, I bought it whilst on a sale but definitely worth full price too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198122276107', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 161, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 145, 'last_played': 1561120340}
review:
Just hit the 2hr mark! Have to say I will not return and keep the game :) I've had this on the watch list for a long time as the price was a little steep for my liking,

I'm learning how to be a game developer and this title is right up my street. I admire most of it.

the graphics are fun and quirky but distorted (maybe used to high res crisp) some sprites appear  like they were upscaled and then downscaled, repeated and then placed into the game.

The music is hit and miss at times, some hit the spot and some are just outta place for the settings.

though my favourite thing about this game is walking into stations and seeing busy environment.

atm 8/10 but more time is needed. 

ps. Keep up the good work

author: {'steamid': '76561198138188652', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 968, 'last_played': 1628606261}
review:
Hi, there all of you space fans out there!! 
3030 Deathwar Redux is, in my opinion, one of the best top-down space sims on the market. It's got everything you need to get going for hours with this game. It's like a time travel to 90's It's got the humor of Monkey Island series,  Privateer and Wing Commander combined :)  Point and click adventure with space battles and many many more. Let's not forget the music because it's awesome!! The Kyoto Connection really makes you feel the H.E.A.T :) It carries a lot of positive vibes throughout the game!

Support the Devs and Buy this game people!! If you like adventure games with good humor and top-down space sim then this is a game for you!! Cheers :D

author: {'steamid': '76561197973112605', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 455, 'last_played': 1567108036}
review:
I had my eye on this game for a while based upon the great reviews that is has been receiving.

I finally bought the game while it was on sale and subsequently played it in an impromptu marathon.

The game has some classic 90s adventure game humor and is embedded in a familiar space age saga of building up your rep, fame and net worth. Anyoen who ever played the old Space Quest games and wish they were open world will love this game!

I highly recommend it for the price tag.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970584939', 'num_games_owned': 1257, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 1312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1312, 'last_played': 1559492712}
review:
[h1]Not just a war. A DEATHwar.[/h1]
[b]3030 Deathwar Redux - A Space Odyssey[/b] is a remake/rerelease of a 2007 space-sim, 3030 Deathwar. In it you control John Falcon, a Han Solo-like who traverses the galaxy, trading, mining and fighting his way through both story missions and open-world content.

[h1]Checkboxes![/h1]
[b]My acquisition:[/b] ☑ Bought on Steam - ☐ Humble Bundle - ☐ Gift - ☐ Other

[b]Did I beat it?[/b] ☑ Yes - ☐ No

[b]Audience:[/b] ☐ Kids - ☑ Everyone - ☐ Casual players - ☐ Pro players

[b]Graphics:[/b] ☐ Potato - ☐ Bad - ☑ OK - ☐ Good - ☐ Beautiful

[b]Audio:[/b] ☐ Mute it - ☐ Bad - ☐ OK - ☑ Good - ☐ Beautiful

[b]Story Quality:[/b] ☐ N/A - ☐ Bad - ☑ Average - ☐ Good - ☐ Fantastic

[b]Controls:[/b] ☐ Bad - ☐ Acceptable - ☐ Good - ☑ Fantastic

[b]Stability:[/b] ☐ Buggy mess - ☐ Some non-game breaking bugs - ☐ Almost perfect - ☑ Stable

[b]Difficulty:[/b] ☐ Too easy - ☑ Easy - ☐ Challenging - ☐ Challenging+ - ☐ Cruel!

[b]When to buy:[/b] ☑ Full price - ☐ Wait for sale - ☐ Never

[b]Requirements:[/b] ☑ Minimal - ☐ Medium - ☐ High end - ☐ Dangerously high

[b]Others:[/b] ☐ Multiplayer - ☑ Single player

[h1]Conclusion/notes:[/h1]
[b]3030 Deathwar Redux - A Space Odyssey[/b] was entertaining from start to finish. I was initially put off by the artstyle, but I am very glad I continued on - there's a pretty enjoyable space sim wrapped up in the odd pixel art and zany story.

[h1]Tl;dr:[/h1]
[list]
[*]Tons of little details
[*]Servicable space-sim
[*]Story is functional and fun, but could be better
[*]Very welcome addition to the genre
[/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561198090737401', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1675, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 474, 'last_played': 1664631468}
review:
A very enjoyable experience with early 80’s-90’s sci-fi charm coming out of the walls. Felt like a "Secret of Monkey Island" in space, complete with chapter screens, bars full of interesting characters, and a villain who was funny and enjoyable but overall competent.

Gameplay is very straight forward. Fly your ships to stations to resupply or purchase tradeable goods, wrecks for a side scrolling looting minigame or engage some dastardly space pirates in combat with missiles and energy weapons.

I very much enjoyed one on one space combat as it felt fast and I found it very rewarding when I had purchased a combat oriented ship and it made short work of enemies, however despite the game including NPC's that invite the characters to space raids or stations being equipped with turrets, group battles are a MESS as a good portion of your shots will miss your intended target and if too many hit a police ship or station, they will ALL turn against you so I now avoid any fight with friendly ships entirely.

While on the subject stations are also some of the best and worst parts of the game. They primarily serve as your mission vendors and resupply areas along with complement of random NPC’s you can talk to or acquire additional missions from. These bars also however serve as the only form of plot progression in the game outside of scripted battle which (as far as I have seen) always take place outside the station, unfortunately this led to me docking at the stations without ever realizing I was under attack causing the game to claim the enemy was dead and continuing the story completely without my knowledge or input which can be disorienting.
 
As far the story NPC’s themselves, they are quite enjoyable with quirky looks and dialogue and felt like a nice compliment to the retro futuristic vibe the game gives. Although these characters cause my biggest problem with the story, that being it is very threadbare and spread thin in my experiences, leaving me invested more in the world itself rather than my main character and his supporting cast.

As my final point if you are looking for a game where you can drift through space with great music, then this will scratch that itch as the music chosen for the soundtrack is fantastic for the setting and really add to the experience.

I highly recommend this to anyone who enjoys the style of point and click adventures but the gameplay of space combat and trading games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976028809', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 2389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1593, 'last_played': 1666677871}
review:
I wish I had not waited for a sale to buy this game.

It's the things I liked about Elite:Dangerous with a whole lot less WORK and a better story. Over 20 hours in, I've spent most of my time mining and scavenging and shopping for upgrades, and very little following the main plot. The plot, what I have seen of it so far, makes me laugh. After catching at least one Star Trek, Star Wars, Pulp Fiction, and several other references, I'm starting to wonder how many subtle references I've missed. 

Sound track is quirky and cool, but can also get on my nerves depending on mood. Fortunately also configurable.

Lots of ships in the most recent update. Lots of *updates* in the most recent update. 

The combat is not particularly complicated but that works for me. Ships and explosions and pretty space stations. Sure, it's pixel chic, but it's really cool pixel chic. 

I like it a lot. You will too. Just buy the darn game already.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995945436', 'num_games_owned': 521, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 4288, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4288, 'last_played': 1538763760}

review:
This a beautiful space faring game in the veins of the classic Escape Velocity series before it.  

The space combat portion just got revamped to add a whole new set of weapons and spaceships, which is always a plus when you get to the endgame.

Also the atmosphere of the whole game gives off a semi cowboy-bebopesque vibe with the smug hero, and the eastern-influenced music when you're piloting the star systems.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073505125', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1890, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1351, 'last_played': 1554051688}

review: Amazing storyline, great humour, amazing music (imo :) and if you don't like it, you can switch the game to play your own!). Lots of options on your career options: salvage derelicts, trade, mine, bounty hunter... A couple of minor bugs and balance issues with some of the ships but the devs are very responsive. If you've ever played Privateer, you will love this game. If you like immersive space games and want to play as a Han Solo/Indiana Jones/Mal Reynolds cross, you will love this game :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198006994725', 'num_games_owned': 601, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 722, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 722, 'last_played': 1541346107}
review: You'll be doing the same few sorts of missions over and over to farm, then the story will have you go fetch stuff at a bunch of far away places, then there's one battle and the game ends. Disappointing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000674344', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2741, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2456, 'last_played': 1550298716}
review:
So if you're looking for a humorous story in a space exploration, this is a good value. 

It starts with a lot of charm, which lasts through a single playthrough. However, since there's basically no scaling to the challenges, once you get the hang of the different aspects, there's not much more to do than keep doing it. Exploration is good for a bit, but you quickly discover that new systems are much like the previous ones.

But that first playthrough was fun, so worth a play for the price, especially when on sale. Just don't expect it to be your "goto game".

author: {'steamid': '76561197989133346', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1776, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1468, 'last_played': 1659891772}
review:
Open World(2D) Space, Action, Adventure, Role Playing Awesomeness.
The Story will give you abut 6-8 hours of gameplay, and just flying around doing what you want can add 10 more.
Eventually it gets repetative and you run out of things to do, but there's a good amount of fun in this game, plus there are mods.
9 out of 10

author: {'steamid': '76561197962083430', 'num_games_owned': 719, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 901, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 857, 'last_played': 1660083875}
review: Imagine if Ron Gilbert decided to make Elite...it would be something like this game! The soundtrack is awesome with some synthwave vibes making for a very cool atmosphere and the story is funny and engaging. The game's universe is refreshingly compact so as not to overwhelm like many other space trader games. It's easy to get into and you can dip in and out when you have a few spare minutes to do a mission or two. Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043968215', 'num_games_owned': 10014, 'num_reviews': 120, 'playtime_forever': 205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 199, 'last_played': 1547202272}
review: This pixely No Man Sky-ish experience has plenty to offer: a captivating space opera, filled with drama, humor and quirky characters; vast spaceship options, including trading, fighting, scavenging. If interstellar travel is something on your taste, as well as pixelart, this can be up your alley. With an eyrie soundtrack to keep you company, as you travel from galaxy to galaxy, trading, fighting or scavenging, from spacestation to spacestation, meeting new interesting characters, grabbing jobs, upgrading your ship or just simply exploring the vast universe, you should buckle up for a real space odyssey.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970385659', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1470, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1056, 'last_played': 1588945715}

author: {'steamid': '76561197990725997', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 360, 'playtime_forever': 389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 389, 'last_played': 1539167342}
review:
I could be critical, but I won't. This game obviously had a lot of effort and love put into it, especially for being 10 years into development. I heard the name in passing, but I finally got a chance to play--the verdict is not disappointing. 

I LOVE this game. I am in my thirties, and this game is a becking to those raised in good old fashioned game styles--but pumped up kicks. It has the nostalgia, humor, graphics, sfx. But what those old games don't have is a finely mastered late 80s synthwave soundtrack! The music is incredible. 

The story is meh, but it's mostly about letting you do your thing while this "meh story" unravels. It works well. 

However, if I had to give it my own score system, it'd be closer to 8/10 in overall gameplay. I heard there was a lot of content, but it seems like you are limited in jobs. There is some meta jokes and meta references to the team itself behind the game, but they aren't well executed for it to be given any extra hype.

I was telling people it was like Wing Commander and Stellar Frontier (old school stardock) had a baby. With some hints of gta2 in space. Stellar Frontier stands out even to today's crowd. If it weren't so outdated on graphics and sound, it would be a killer game still. SF has population control, colonization, planet destruction, asteroid mining, asteroid launching (as weapons, space station building, faction changing gameplay and I only wish it was like that, but it feels similar. It has its own charm. 

SFX: 7/10
Soundtrack: 9/10
Graphics as intended: 9/10
Story: 6/10
Gameplay: 8/10
Replay Value: 5/10 
Overall: 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197977433760', 'num_games_owned': 1034, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 727, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 697, 'last_played': 1539071417}
review:
Excellent game! Great story, great interface, great combat. 

You can be a taxi driver, errand runner, trader, miner, bounty hunter, pirate, or just follow the story and see where you go.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066167777', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 1698, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1698, 'last_played': 1538370104}
review: 3030 Deathwar Redux is those games that brings back old school memory from its core. The story is great, humour and fun. Everything is done very very well. Loved the music and the old school graphics, controls are done well too. You fly station to station, doing quests while the plot is being uncover as you go. I really have nothing bad to say but highly recommend it to everyone who love old school type of games. There is definitely a lot of love put in it. I can only hope a sequel will come, but given the time it took to deveop this game, 10 years for what I read?....... Either way, no regrets and loads of fun. Thank you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979918816', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1539218281}
review:
This game is...

It's a mix of a point and click adventure game (not on rails) and an Open World "Freelancer" type with pirates, missions, trading, etc.  I really enjoy it - I ferried around passengers and hauling missions until I found that salvaging derelicts is way more profitable (mini game - go in, explore, shoot, loot).  Now I can afford a better ship with more guns...

I do recommend this.  It has character.  It is also super cheap, so just get it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970488876', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 495, 'last_played': 1537216920}
review:
Thus far, at 8 hours of game play at the time of this review, this game has been a complete joy to play. I would totally reccomend this game at $15 and would consider it a steal if on sale.

3030 Deathwar Redux has a nice mix of play mechanics including a flight system reminiscent of Asteroids and Star Control, plus some side scrolling environments for derelict ships and space stations. There is a lot of flexibility in play style which includes space combat, mining, trading, bounty hunting, pirating, delivery jobs, taxi service jobs and more. As you play, it steadily unlocks incremental upgrade options, with the cost increasing a little faster than your income growth curve is likely to increase. I believe that eventually you can unlock every performance upgrade for your ship, but that along the way you will focus on the upgrades that have the biggest impact to your chosen playstyle. Every playstyle has a few ship archetypes that should fit your needs, and each ship archetype has about 9 tiers to work your way through; plenty of enjoyable moments where you move on to that new ride. All performance upgrades carry over from ship to ship, which is a nice touch.

Changing playstyles is not an impossibility, although some are easier to adjust to on-the-fly versus others. For instance, most combat craft have minimal cargo capacity, so going from bounty hunting to trading will probably require a ship swap. On the other hand, mining and trading both require cargo capacity so you can easily do either or both with the same ship archetype. I've only played with tiers 1-3 of various ships, so my impressions are heavily based on those. It's clear from examining the higher tier ships that their differences do get a bit more extreme down the line. They do have one archetype called the Allrounder which does a decent job at most playstyles from what I have seen, although I have not fought too heavily with it, as yet.

Having looked through some comments, it looks like there have been a lot of quality of life improvements to the game since it was launched. Everything from a game experience perspective has been pretty smooth since I started. I side stepped the main story early on and have enjoyed the open world nature of the game, although I intend to get back into the story shortly. The humor is great, whether it's the storyline or a random bar conversation.

That pretty much covers my thoughts on the game. I hope you enjoy it as much as I have.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050016554', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 517, 'playtime_forever': 297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1536910470}
review:
Même si 3030 Deathwar transpire la passion j'ai du mal à le trouver aussi génial que les avis positifs le laissent penser. Ce que j'en ai vu pour l'instant n'est rien de plus qu'un genre de Freelancer en 2D et gros pixels: chasseur, marchand, collecteur en toute liberté et répétitivité avec une vague histoire à détricoter. Avec en prime le qwerty obligatoire (même si on s'en sort avec les flèches), ça donne l'impression qu'il est juste sorti 15 ans trop tard.

Autant ce gameplay marche bien avec du visuel à perte de vue et du dogfight 3D, autant là je dois avouer que je ne comprends pas trop à qui s'adresse ce jeu. Ce n'est pas assez axé sur l'histoire pour être du RP, la gestion se limite à du commerce et de la collecte manuels avec notre unique vaisseau très loin de la gestion flottes/usines d'un X3 et le combat 2D est trop simple par rapport à des titres comme Drox Operative ou Space Rangers HD par exemple. Ouais, je suis perplexe. Pourtant au vu des évaluations il a un public, question de goût, lisez d'autres avis.

Moyen moins, je le trouve trop cher dans sa catégorie. Prenez-le en promo.

review:
What a cool game! The gameplay setup - where you switch between flying your ship and walking around like an old adventure game - is clever, why is this not more of a thing? Having a real character that walks up to a trading window feels a lot more immersive than just having a spreadsheet pop up when your ship docks, like in other similar games.

There's a ton of dialogue and flavor text, an engaging story, and a big map to explore. This is a super fun game, particularly for the price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026036626', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2024, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1663, 'last_played': 1568408229}
review:
For old fans of sandbox space games -- Elite, Privateer, etc., etc. -- Deathwar is a treat. It is faithful to the genre: the player goes on missions, flies between systems, mines, shoots bogeys, runs out of fuel, and earns cash to buy better equipment and ships. It is, obivously, in the 2D top-down stream of these games. From here, this sounds like many many clones, and not worth getting, but Deathwar stands out in a few big ways.

I think most importantly, this game drips with personality and charm. From the weird people on space stations, to the radio chatter, to the pirate base that looks like a giant head, Deathwar has character. That character is decidedly retro: half the music tracks are 90s pop inspired, the main character wears a leather jacket, and its kinda-sorta pixel art. This is partly why long-time lovers of the genre, who may be of a certain age range, will find some extra nostalgic charm here: the game does not take itself too seriously, and is definitely winking to you about the genre you love.

At the same time, the core gameplay is solid, and the main story line is a good way to keep things moving (my advice: don't rush through it; take your time and build up your credits). Most of the different paths to earning money are viable to an extent, and fun to at least try out. There are some nice twists on the old mission type standbys, like towing cargo between stations, and two very nice additions I havent' seen elsewhere: salvage missions, in which you play a side-view mini-game to guide your character around busted ships looking for survivors and loot; and a space sporting event, where you and many other ships chase a moving goal around a system. This all works, and there is still an immersive element. 

What are the space fligth mechanics like? There's a bit of momentum as you fly your ship around, and turning is slow, but it will automatically come to a stop, and you have a max speed -- so non-Newtonian. Combat is fairly simplistic, with guns, missiles, afterburners, and ECM systems. It's not hard, and a bit samey. The general pacing is a little like the Elite/Frontier games, where you definitely are waiting around for a minute to travel between systems. Unlike Elite, the universe is not infinite or random/procedural: it is hand-made, with around 30 systems to explore. There is some in-game hand-waving about why this is, but I think it works: the systems have some distinctions betweent them, and there's no real need for more.

In the end, this is a charming and fun game. It might not have the longevity of some of the bigger open-ended games, but we'll also have to see what the modders come up with. It's not expensive, so grab it if you like this kind of thing.
